Eccle. 38. Altissimus creauit de terra medicinam, and vir prudens non
abhorrebit illam.

BVLLEINS Bulwark of Defense against all Sickness, Soarenesse, and Wounds
that do daily assault mankind: Which Bulwark is kept with Hilarious the
Gardener, and Health the Physician, with the Chirurgian, to help the Wounded
Soldiers. Gathered and practiced from the most worthy learned, both old and
new: to the great comfort of Mankind: by William Bullein, Doctor of Physic.
1562.

IMPRINTED At London by Thomas Marshe, dwellinge in Fleetestreate near unto
Saint Dunstanes Churh. 1579.

Cicero. 1. Offic. Eos quoru^ vita perspecta est in rebus honestis, and been de
Rep. sentientes obseruare and colere solemus.



TO THE RIGHT HONOrable Lord Henry Carry Baron of Hunsdon, and Knight of the
most noble order of the Garter: William Bulleyn wishes all health, and perfect
felicity in Christ.
Mankind, which is called of the Philosopher, Microcosmos, Orbiculus, or a
little World, having in it self, either Misery, Felicity, or a Mean: although
it be of the most beautiful Form, and fairest Shape, excelling all other
living Creatures upon Earth: And also is rightly endued with goodly gifts of
Nature, in whose Brain is fixed the Jewel called Reason, the Mother of Art,
and Science, by whom be wrought, and Invented marvelous things, whereby our
eternal GOD is perceived in us his Creatures, more abundantly, than in the
high Lyghtes mooueable, and fixed in the Fyrmament of Heaven: whose natural
influences be known unto Mankind. Even so be the virtues of every Creature
here in Earth: as Beast, Foul, Fyshe, Serpent, Trees, Plants, Fruictes,
Flower, Herb, Grass, Gum, Stone, and Metal. There is nothing so secret
hidden, within the Mynerals of the Earth, or lurking so low under the Floudes
of the Sea: but by means, and policy, they are brought to use. Their Names,
Qualities, and Natures are known unto the witty Head of Mankind: to this
end, to help Mankind in the time of his bodily infirmity. These has GOD
ordained by his dyuine providence, that every Creature sensible, and
insensible, should serve his best Creature, Mankind. Luke. 1.
To this end, that he should serve GOD in righteousness, and holiness, all the
days of his life, for these his Gifts. And the Philosopher says, in libro de
Coelo, and Mundo: Deus, and Natura nihil frustra agunt: GOD, and Nature does
nothing in vain, but are ever working, and doing: he the pryncipall cause, and
they his effect. Yet for all these syngular Uertues, gieuen to Man: through the
continuance of time, Calamities of this World, Wounds in the Body, corruption
of the Air, abundance of Humors. etc. the same Mankind does decay, dye,
and return unto the Dust, and become as though he had never bin: although he
be never so honorable, yea or poor, death does make equality between them.
Every man's course is appointed, they cannot prolong their time:
notwythstanding, Job. 14.
GOD has ordained sundry Means, by his Mynisters, to help Mankind in the
time of Sycknesse, to ease their pains, and heal their Wounds. And I being a
Child of the Common wealth, am bound unto my Mother, that is, the Land in
which I am borne: to pleasure it, with any good gift, that it has pleased GOD
to bestow upon me: not fo this end, to instruct the learned, but to help the
ignorant, that they may resort to this little Bulwarcke, which I do Dedicate
unto your honorable Lordship. Where they shall not only be defended in the
same, from sickness, and Wounds: but also being wounded, through cruel
Assaulters of this Bulwark, or Sick, here eftsoons they shall have at hand,
all manner of Cordials, and wholesome Salues. Whereby they shall be the abler, to
keep this Hold against all bodyly evils: which I do call Soarenesse, and
Sickness: for whose sakes, I have builded this little Fort calling it my
Bulwark. Not being able to build any bigger work of defense against
Sickness, or evil Diet: as that Man of worthy memory, Sir Thomas Eliot Knight
did, when he builded his Castle of Health, a Book very profitable. Would GOD,
that all Men of Worship in their calling, were likewise disposed to their
Country, as he was, and many more, whose names I do commend unto the Reader,
within this little Bulwark. And although there will be many peradventure,
both malicious, spightfull, and cankred of Mind, that both with slander and
disdain, will lay their Battry, against this Fort: I shall be able ever to
repulse them, through your Lordshippes good aid. For I have builded it very
low, wanting neither the strength of Ordinance, prouysion of Uictualles, nor
the Pollycie of most worthy Captains, and good Souldeours: as Hippocrates,
Galen, Dioscorides. etc. Now finally, I shall most humbly desire your good
Lordshyp, to take this simple Book, as an Argument of my good Zeal and Love,
that I bare unto you, for your goodness toward me. For if I were otherwise
able, to gratify your Honor, according to my bounden Duty: I would not leave
it undone, as knows GOD, who ever give your Lordship continuance of Honor,
and prosperous Health.

From London. In March. 1562. Your Lordshippes ever to command: William
Bulleyn.

TO THE Friendly Reader, William Bulleyn sends Salutacion.
FOr as mutch good Reader, as four years last past, I promised (in a Book of
mine, called the Government of health, which I dedicated to a Knight of great
worship in the North, called Sir Thomas, the Baron of Hilton) to set forth an
other Book of healthful Medicines: Even so, by the space of one year next
after the same, I trauayled to perform my Promise made, and so finished my
Copy: which Copy did perish in Shipwreck, and so my Labor was lost. And not
only my Labor, but also my Life, by sundry malicious and deuilishe Inventions,
by, and through one William Hilton: in nature, Brother to the foresaid Baron of
Hilton, but in Conditions, nothing like at all: for he wanted his gentleness,
and good nature. Now, after that God had delivered me from the great peril of
this Man, that is to say: conspiring of my giltles death, and hurtlesse life,
toward him and his: Eftsoons this man attempted an other new displeasure
against me for debt: coloring his Malice by a pretense of law. By which
Action, finally I was imprisoned, me thought a long time (for there are but
few Ghestes, that have pleasure in such Innes.) And being thus in Prison, me
thought I had not only convenient time, but also a quiet Conscience, to
travel, in renewing my late Book, or lost Copy, which in deed, I am not able
to finyshe, being prevented with so many Troubles, and Lets of my said Enemy,
whose doings at large, I commit to silence, least I should seem to write, a
Story or Tragedy, or else a description of his folly, in the place of Physic:
no less also can I, but declare some cause of my let, and why my Book came
not forth ere this time. accordingly as I promised. But blame me not, good
Reader, although I put him in my Book, which would have put me from this
Life. And this Book, which I have done, Gentle Reader, take it in good part, I
pray you, for that is my desire.

First, I have made you a Book of Simples, as Herbs, Fruictes. etc. For I had
no small pleasure in the natures of them, being moved of the Heathen men, so
to do: whose names do, and ever shall remain, among such as read of Simples.
Galen commends unto us, ye love and cunning ye Orpheus, Museus, Hesiodus,
Homerus, and Rufus Ephesius had in Herbs. Who can forget Lysimachus, a worthy
noble Capitayn to Alexander? who, when he was wounded very deep, found an herb
which healed him, and called ye same herb, by his own name: Artemisia a noble
Queen, called Mugwort, after her own name. Helena found first ye virtue of
Enulacampana. Gentian was named by Gentias king of Illyria: with many mo noble
Men and Women, which delited in the Flowers, and Fruictes of the ground whose
names for ye most part you shall find in the Simples. I cannot forget Attalus,
the king of the less Asia, and Euax a king of Arabie, who wroate good Books
to Nero the Emperor: with many good Worckes of Compoundes. Among all,
Dioscorides a noble Knight of Egypt, which served Antonius, and Cleopatra,
like a worthy Soldier in the Field: and excelled all other in the Noble
knowledge of Herbs. etc. Let us not forget, the passing Wisdom of Solomon,
who had knowledge most excellent in natural Philosophy, as well as Moral: and
taught the Queen of Saba all the virtues of herbs. How worthy were Archelaus
King of Cappadocia, and Agamemnon Prince of the Argiues, which were noble
Kings, yet were they Heathen, saving Solomon. Whose chief delights, were not
in Bacchus Bankets, or Venus Games: but spent their time pleasauntly, in the
sweet Fields among Fruictes, Flowers, and Spices of delight. Would GOD in
such Uertues, the Chrystians were their Equalles. When you have read the
Simples following, then approaches the Chirurgian Plaster, and Salve prepared
ready, to make whole the wounded Man helped by Hippocrates, Galen, and Auicen
to finishe his cunning cure. Then comes the Apothecarie Nicholaus, with rich
Cordials, Pills, Electuaries, and Purgations of each kind, with his master
the Physician, who does dispense every Medicine in Time, Place, Quantity, and
good order, to his Pacient with good Diet, travel, sleep: and finally, ye
perturbacions of the Mind. At which place good Reader, I should have declared
of other Judgments, as Pulse, Uryne, and the proper Cures of every Fever,
afflicting the Body: which hereafter, by Gods grace, I shall bring to pass, if
time will suffer me to live. And until such time, most gentle Reader, take
this in good part, from the hands of him, who thincketh it well bestowed upon
thee, if courteously thou do receive the same again. Thus fare thou heartily
well. Thine ever to his small power.

William Bulleyn.

Thomas Newton to the Freendly Reader.
DUe proof does show, so does Experience teach
That handcraftsmen (when Su^ne is gone to glade)
If slender light their weary Eyes empeach,
Or hindre them, in that their toyling trade,
(For that their sight is dim with darkness made)
Of custom use to covet open Air,
And bring their work into more lightsome layre.
The Mind of Man in Bodies Prison kept
Is pressed down, and fetired lies full fast*
All rest, all case, all Joy is from it swept,
Unless it be reuiu'de with souereygne taste
Of sacred Lore, or worthy Woork^s forepast:
By which one mean, it bayles it self from Gyeues,
And (mauger Spite) with comfort great suruiues.
This work thus pend by Bulleins busy brain,
With travail, toil, expense, and mickle charge
(Which proves and shows how glad he was and fayn^
To help each sort, and set his Mind at large:
As one (saunce f^are) by help of Palias (Targe)
He franckly here unto the learned Crew
Beequeathes and gives with friendly eye to view.
It was at first but roughly hewn out
Himself that time in Prison fast detayned,
No marvel the^, though scapes and faults did sprout,
Sith he the while from liberty was wayned:
Yet his goodwill, his skill, and love unfeigned
He kept not back, but offered it to all,
In hope thereby to pleasure great and small.
If God on high had lent him longer days
He would the same have repecus'd again
And brought in frame, as mountain Bear astates
With licking Tongue, her whelps in shope to train:
But gone he is, with Christ above to raygne:
He plainly spoke, he plainly wrate also,
His Lyte, and Speech did both together go.
His pleasant Pen, his merry Mind, and Wit
Did most men please, yea all of judgment found:
Tried truth he told, and nail on head he hit:
Examples stoare in all his Books are found.
Whose sap and fruict does to each sex redound.
Blind Empiricke, ne Doggeleach could he brook,
No cosening Mate, no popish Clawback^s look.
In lieu of pains thus taken for thy sake,
Afoorde him thanks, and good report withal:
Of Ashes his so may thou some awake,
As pressed as he, t'assist thee in thy thral.
Few faults (I trust) and they but very small
Are left beehinde: God grant to thee, and me
(Good Reader) grace our faults, and sins to flee.
1579. Thomas Newtonus, Cestreshyrius.

Ad adyta virtuti aditus.
THE BOOK OF SIMPLES.
Marcellus. FIrst of al, my friend Hilarious, because I have no small grief in
my breast, Azarabaccha or w^^de Nardus.
I shall desire you, to show me the nature of an herb called Asaron, which I
trust will help me by the way of vomit.


Hilarious. PLinius remembering this herb lib. xj. cap. xiij. and lib. 21. cap.
6. among al other flowers or herbs (says he) it is utterly refused,
Azarabaccha is br^ader in Italy, then here in England.
and not worthy to be preferred among pleasant Garlands, or sweet Nos^gaies,
because of the baseness, and bitterness of his nature. In form says he, it
is not unlike unto Iuie leaves: notwithstanding it is rounder, softer, and
brother: it is mutch like unto Vngula, called Foales foot. Dioscorides with
whom none has ever been comparable hetherunto, for the excellent invention,
and knowledge of herbs, lib. 1. cap. ix. says that the leaves be of the
foresaid form. And is so hot, that it does vehemently bite the tongue, but in
virtue it provoke urine, helps the dropsy, and painful ache of the huckle
bone called Sciatica. Six dragmes of the roots of Asaron, sodden in sweet
water, the same water drunken will draw forth the terms in women. Asaron
provoke terms* and helps Sciatica.
Galen lib. 6. simpli* medi. speaking of the roots of Asaron says, they be
like to Acorus, but yt is marvelous it should so be: for Acorus will not
provoke strong vomites, as Asaron will. Therefore Dioscorides has said the
truth, and Mesue says, that Asaron has the virtue of Elleborus, to purge both
up and down, Choler* and fleume, which Acorus cannot do so: it is hot, and
dry in the third degree. In Latin it is called Vulgago, it provoke urine,
cleanses the matrix, Asaron does help the Liver and stomach.
helps the liver from all grie^e, Raynes, Stomach, Belly, and Spleen. etc. in
the laud thereof, having these virtues as I have said from Dioscorides, and
Mesue, Marcus Aemilius affirms the same, saying: Asaron in Greek, Vulgago in
Latin, heat, and dry in the iij. degree, provoke Urine, and purges terms
menstruoli and takes away the pains of the Liver.
Est Asaron Graece, vulgago dicta Latin,
Haec calidae and siccae virtutis dicitur esse,
Tertius est illi gradus, vt dicunt in vtroque.
Prouocat vrinam, potataque menstrua purgat,
Hocque modo iecoris medicatur sumpta dolori:
Here have three notable learned men, declared the virtue of Asaron.
Furthermore, if the juice of six leaves, be strayned with a pint of Whale,
specially of Goats milk, and drunk in the morning: This Drink in Summer,
will cast forth yellowe Choler, and unnatural Fleume. For in Summer vomets
ought to be taken, to cleanse the upper parts, as the lower members be purged,
by electuaries in Winter. Furthermore, 20. Leaves do seen in iniust on, but
other ways three, sower, or five do suffice,
xxx. green leaves steeped in new Wine all the night, and strained in the
morning, drink this against all the abundance of humors in the Breast, or
precordial parts, in this manner. Power this wine into a close pot, with a
piece of fat Porke, and sees the same: then let the Pacient eat of the Porke,
and then drink the Wine, or else the Wine may be drunk after the Porke, simply
diluted or steeped all the night with the leaves, and never to be sodden with
ye Porke. This will help the Iaundice, Asaron good against Dropsy. Fe^ers.
and frenzy.
and if it be drunk of any body, which has a Tercian being first digested:
and specially not on the sick day, it will clean deliver from the said
Tercian: in the beginninges of Hydropsies, Timpani^s, Quotidians, green
Sickness, Quartaynes, Worms, and swellinge in the Stomach, there is no better
reamedy, than to drink this, as in the manner aforesaid: For a weak frantike
Brain, coming of an extreme cold, when Melancholy is placed in the ma^sion
of reason, through which, the principal Senses be obscured and darkened: shave
the Moulde of the head, and wash the same with Wine, wherein Calamintes,
Rosemary, Lignum Aloes, and Asaron have bin sodden, and then anoint the head
with the oils of Maces, Mintes, and Asaron warm, purging the head with
Pills of Hierae simplex, and abstayning from such meats, as wyllingender
Melancholy, or make exhalation, or Smoke up into the Brain. The juice of
Asaron tempered with Nill, The Arabians call that Nill which we name Visc^m or
Missiltowe Lib, primo Paradox. Cap. xxvj.
called Missiltow, and strayned with a little Rosewater, will cleanse the dark
sight of the Eyes, and make them clear. And thus I end of herb Asaron,
which has virtue against Choler: would God it had the like effect, to cleanse
Disdain, rankor, and malice, so that grace, that most precious herb, might
be replanted again in each man's breast, which the Devil has supplanted
through pride.


Marcellus. What is Asplenon, called Scolopendrion, or Citrache, and
Hemionitis, leaued like Dragons, and Phyllitis, called Hearts tongue, good for?


Hilarious. Asplenon good for the Spleen.
TO this herb Asplenon, no herb may be compared, for his singular virtue, to
help the sickness, or grief of the Spleen, the place of Melancholy. It is
called Scolopendrion, of a speckled Worm with many feet. This herb is a
small Fern, growing among stones, neither having stalk, flower, or seed: the
leaves be yellowe by neath, and green above. There is an other herb of the
same virtue, Hemionitis leaued like Dragons.
for the spleen called Hemionitis, whose leaves be mutch like Dragons, with
many small roots: these said heroes dye not, and be hoate in the first, and
dry in the second degree. Goodly Sirupes are made of them for the Spleen:
Diosco. lib. 3. Capi. 134.
they be very good in decoction for ye same: if one do drink of this herb
sodden in Uineger, by the space of.40. days, it has virtue to consume ye
spleen: this herb has virtue to help the Iaundice, stone, stra^gury, Galen.
lib. 5. S^^. medica. Capi. xij.
hicket, or wind, and Capper barks, Tamarice roots, Scolopendrion, and
Scilla sodden by art together, will help the Spleen. There is an herb called
Phyllitis, or Hearts tongue, growing in dark places, which is partly of the
nature of the said herbs, which has singular virtue, both for man and beast,
to be drunk against poison, and bloody flixes, or flowing of terms immoderat
in Women. But many now a days, have such passions of the Spleen Cancred with
melancholy, The spleneticke love.
corrupted with disdain, and with golden words, louinge only from the
Spleen, and not from the Heart, that they give each other the curtesy of the
tongue, without the consent of the heart: and thus I conclude of heartlesse
Tongue, and Hearts tongue, the one of comfort, the other of decay. Lingua
fallax non amat veritatem, Proverb. 27. d*
and os lubricum operatur ruinas.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Wormewodde? that bitter herb called
Absynthium?


Hilarious. Absinthium is a common herb: it is of diverse kinds, as Ponticum,
Wormwood.
and Romanum. etc. it is hoate in the first and dry in the second, and it is
very bitter, and being dried, keeps clothes from worms and mothes, and the
Sirupes thereof eaten before wine, preserves Men from dronke^nesse: if it be
sodden in Uyneger* it will help the sores that breeds in the Ears: beeinge
laid warm upon it: it is to be drunk against swellinge of the Stomach.
And Ophthalmia which is a Syckenesse of the Eyes, is greatly helped with
Wormewodde* Sore ears.
if it be stamped and made luke warm with Rosewater, For the Eyes
and put into a clean Walnut shell: the Syrup heals the blouddy Flux
bound to the Belly: Blouddy flux
it does help a cold Stomach, if it be drunk.x. days, Cold Stomachs.
every morninge two spoonefull of the Syrup: it is also good against the
Dropsy. And thus says Auicen, Fygges, Cockle. Wormwood, and Niter stamped
together, Dropsies.
and made in a Plaster, is good against the disease of the Spleen, Auicen.
lib. 2.
and also kills Worms in the Belly, used in the foresaid manner: Simp. 2,
one dragme of the Powder may be drunk at once in Wine: For ye spleen.
it has many goodly virtues, as the Wine thereof being drunk, against
Dropsyes, coldness of the Stomach, Wind, Swellings: Wormwood has many
virtues.
if a handefull be sodden in.viij. pound of clean Water or Wine, in a
vessel of Silver, Glass, or Stone, putting in sweet Calamus, Cynamon, the
flowers of Cassia, Squinance, Spikenarde, and Dates of each..iiij. beaten all
together and sodden, as is aforesaid: or else these things put in a vessel of
new Wine with a linen bag, and so kept close.ij. months, and afterward
drunk of them that have either the yellow Iaundice, pains in the Raynes,
lothesomnesse of the Stomach, stopping of terms, swelling after meat,
continuance of Uomites, cold passions of the heart. etc. this virtue has
Wormwood Wine says Dioscorides, libro qum. Cap. 40. Furthermore gather a. l
i. of Wormwood leaves, and stamp them in a Mortar of stone, and then put unto
the same. l i.iiij. of the best white Sugar, and so beat them together until
they be come to one substance, keep this in a close Pot or Glass. And this is
the virtue thereof, says that well learned Man Matthiolus, A goodly medicen
for Hydropsie.
it helps the Dropsy, if the Pacient eat every day of this half an
ounce.iij. hours before meat, and with this I have known many helped, says
he, and as for the virtue of the syrup of Wormewoode, it shall come in his
place accordingly.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Anisseede?


Hilarious. IT is much like unto Fenell seed, and is called Romayne Fenell,
Galen de sim. Opens the Raynes.
it is warm and sweet, and hoate in the second, and dry in the third degree:
the new Seeds be best, it engenders vital Seed, if opens the stoppyng of
the Raynes and Matrix, being drunk with Ptisanes or clean temperate Wine:
this herb or seed is comfortable in sweet compounded medicines or in powder
for shortness of breath, and soreness of the lunges: and also is good to be
sodden in Ptisanes, made of Barley, to be drunk in the Fever Quotidiane bred of
Phlegm: it ingendreth Milk in the breasts drunk with sweet Wine or Milk: it
provoke vryne, makes sweet breath, and is good against the Collike or wind
of ye great Guts, being drunk with good white Wine and Sugar, and also
stops the whites which runs oftentimes from the bodies of Women: the
powder thereof, Tamarix.
with the pouders of Fenell, Gallingale, Spicknarde, Tamarix, Nutmegges, and
Graynes of Paradise, called Cardamomum, tempered with Wheat flower, A good
remedy for the ru^ninge of the Raynes.
water and red Wine, and so baked in manchets or cakes, is most wholesome to be
eaten of them which have the running of the Raines, wasting of Nature, moist
Dropsyes, or of them in whom the humor of phlegm does greatly abound, through
humidity, wind, or cold, and this was proved to help a Lady which was sick
of a Timpany, and was sir Thomas the Baron Hiltons wife, within the Byshopprike
of Duresme, which used this Bread during one half year, and also once a
month was purged with wholesome Electuaries accordingly, and blood letting: and
thus I conclude of Amsseede the best whereof comes from Egypt.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of a Mouse ear, which is like the ear of
Mouse, and full of hair, in form mutch like the ear of a Mouse?


Hilarious. AN herb commonly known, cold and moist in the first degree as
Galen says, a decoction of this herb sodden in water with sugar, Falling
sickness.
is good against the Falling sickness, being oftentimes drunk and a leaf
thereof put into the Nose, it will provoke sternutation or neesing, Neesing,
which wonderfully does cleanse the veins: and sodden in white Wine, Ptisane
or Borage water, with Sugar candy, this is good against pains in the Throat,
Mouse ear helps the Throat.
called Angina, and Dioscorides writes but little of this herb. And Galen
says, in the.vij. lib. of Simples, that it is dry in the second degree: and it
grows in May upon Hills, Meddowes, and Waysides, says Matthiolus upon
Dioscorides. Furthermore if it be stamped with Madder, and the great Plantein
roots, and an herb called Sheperdes purse, and so sodden in red Wine and
strayned out, and so put into a little drink warm, this is also good against
the blouddy Flux, or a broken Uayne within the Body of one, Against the
blouddy flixe.
which has fallen into some deep place, and this was proved by a young man
dwelling in Newcastel, which fell into a deep Coal pit, whose outward wounds
were healed by an ancient Practicioner called Michell a Frenchman, who also is
cunninge to help his own country disease, Michell the Chyrurgian of Newcastle
that now is to commonly known here in England (the more to be lamented) but
yet daily increased, whereof I entende to speak of in the place of the Pox.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Garlyke?


Hilarious. GArlyke is very hot and dry in the fourth degree, Garlike.
it troubles the Stomach of Cholorike men, it is hurtful to the Eyes, and
Head, it increases dryness, Provoke vryne.

Biting of a Snake.

Hemeroydes.


but it will provoke Uryne, and is good to be laid upon the biting of a Snake,
or Adder, it is good for the Emeroydes, applied to the sore place being first
stampte: if it be sodden, the stink thereof is taken from it, Coughes.
but the virtue remains to be eaten against coughes and pain in the Lunges,
it cutteth, and consumes corrupt Fleume, and brings sleep, it is not good
for hot Men, and Women with Children, Corrupt Fleume.
or Nurses giving Milk to Children: but Galen calls it the common Peoples
Treacle. If Sanguyne Men eat mutch of it, it will make the^ to have read
Faces, but is a special remedy against Poison, Against poison.
and a hoate Plaster applied to the biting of a mad Dog, made of Garlyke,
helps it: if it be drunk it kills Worms in the Belly. For Tothach
And Garlyke stamped with Mastike, and put into the mouth, does aswage the
Dolor of the Teeth. Garlyke dried or burnt into Powder, To increase hair.
and tempered with Honey and Bears Grease, is good to anoint a baulde head to
recover hair: and all this and more reports Dioscorides, which excelled in
herbs. Plinius reports, if it be stamped and made in a Gargarisme, it
heals the Angina, it helps the Throat, with Oil of Quinces and so warm
applied to the Belly it is good against the Collicke, and the blouddy Flux.
New Ale, and Garlyke, kills Worms to be drunk: A medicine for the fistulo.
it is good to be eaten against the Falling evil. And Garlike heals
Fistulaes tempered with Pitche, Brimstone and Rosen, made hoate in a Tente.
These with such like virtues do Plinius, Aetius, Galen. etc. report: but it
is a gross kind of Medycine, very unpleasant for fair Ladies, and tender
Lylly Rose colloured Damselles, which often times prefer sweet breathes
before gentle Words: but both would do very well.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Honey, the Fruictes of Bees labor, and their
Summers travel?


Hilarious. AVERHOIS says, Auerhois. 5 Simeon Sethi.
Honey is hoate and dry in the second degree, and does cleanse very mutch, and is
a medicinable meat, most chiefly for old Men, and Women, Ill for chollerike
persons.
for it does warm them and conuerteth in them to good blood. It is not good
for Chollericke persons, because of the heat and dryness: they do greatly
err that say Honey is hoate, and moist, but if it be claryfied from his Wax,
and dross, and kept in a close vessel, there is nothing liquid upon the earth
that remains longer. And this precious Jewel Honey has bin ever more praised,
for it will conserve and keep any fruit, Honey is an heavenly dew.
herb or root, or any other thing that is put into it, an exceeding long
time. Plinius writes of a Monster which was long kept in Honey in Claudius
days. Merueylous is the work of God, Honey being an heavenly dew that falls
upon flowers and leaves as Auicen says, Auicen. Can. 2. cap. 504.
and is neither Juice of leaves nor fruicts, but only the heavenly dew,
whereunto the Bees in Summer in due time do resort and gather the said Honey,
Bees be an example unto us, both for love and workinge in the commonwealth.
and lay it up in store, in their curious houses builded, whereas they dwell
together in most goodly order. O Bees, Bees, how mutch happier are you than
many wretched men, which dwell never together in unity and peace, but in
continual discord, and vnqui^tnes, as Virgill says: En quo discordia ciues
perduxit miseros? Virgill.
Behold whither discord has brought wretched Cityzens. But now to speak of
the most excellent virtues of Honey, New Honey.
it is good in the meats of them that be Fleumatike. Honey newly taken out of
the Combs is partly laxatiue, and clarified Honey does bind, and dry up
Fleume, Clarified Honey does bind
and keep the bodies of Fleumatike and old persons from corruption. The best
Honey is gathered in the Spryng time, the second in Summer, but that which is
gathered in Winter is ill, and hurtful. One part of Honey, and some part of
water sodden together until the Froth be all scommed of, An healthful drink
for Summer.
and when it is cold, kept in a close stone Pot, this drink (says Galen) is
wholesome for Summer, it cleanses the Lunges, and preserves the body in health.
Oximel simplex, and Compos^tum, be made with Honey, Pandect. cap. 347.
and so be many mo things, which be of great virtue. Also the aucthour of the
Pandect, says yt Honey poured into a new wound yt eftsoons it cleanses and
makes it whole. Honey mingled with a little Salt, and poured warm into the
ear, kills Worms that breed there: The same also kills Lyce, if
Childrens heads be anointed therewith. Rub young Chyldrens Gummes with clean
Honey every day and it will easily cause their Teeth to grow. Honey mingled with
Oil of Roses, and so drunk incontinently, will cause one to vomit when he
has eaten any venomous thing, as rotten Moushromes, called Fungi. etc. Also
Gargarismes and Suppositories be made of Honey, the one does cleanse the
Throat, and the other does relaxe the Belly. Serpigo. Cost.

To cure Serpigo.


There is an infection in the skin, through the corruption of the Liver,
which is called Serpigo, oftentimes in the Paulme of the hand, chiefly in the
right hand, specially in Chollerike persons* which is helped with Honey mingled
with Cost, and anointed warm every day twice. To cleanse the Face.
Also the distilled Water of Honey has virtue to make clean the skin of them
whose Faces be unclean: but most chiefly if it be stilled with strong
Uineger, Milk, and the Urine of a Boy, and so with a Sponge wash the Face to
bedward, and let it dry in of it self. The goodly Ointment called Vnguentum
Aegiptiacum, which cleanses all corrupt humors, and wounds being rotten
within, the chief thing in this Ointment is Honey: it is marvelous that they
which use to eat Honey daily, and daily anoint their Stomachs with Oil of
Wormwood, should either die suddenly, or live paynefully, or be evil colloured
in their Faces. The people of Wales do use to drink Mede, Welchmens drink.
and Metheglyne, and under Heaven there is no fayrer people of complexion, nor
cleaner of nature, To increase Hair.
Anoynte the head being new shaven with Bears grease and Honey mingled
together, and it preserves the hair from falling. Honey of Roses is a goodly
Medicine, outwardly in wounds, and inwardly cleanses fleume, mundifieth the
Stomach, and opens the mouth of the veins, and also is good to put in the
Eyes to cleanse them.


Marcellus. I Did never here any thing so greatly commended as thou have
commended Honey: if it be true that thou have spoken, there be but few things
may be compared to it, for the excellent virtue of it.


Hilarious. BE not in doubt of the truth thereof, for the best Aucthours have
taught me, Exodus.
and daily experience moves me, thus mutch to report of Honey: I ought to
think no shame thereof. In asmutch as the God of Heaven, and Earth, maker of
all Creatures, did give his people of Israel no greater blessing than a land
which did flow with Milk, and Honey. And often times amongst ye Blessings of
GOD, sweet Honey. is rehearsed. The Prophet David in the Psalms, does often
name Honey, Psalms.
and the Honey Comb, making a comparison beetweene it and the word of God.
In some of the holy Sacrifices, Honey was brought in for an Offering, before the
Lord GOD into his holy Temple, Iudic. 14.
the strong Nazareth of GOD Judge of Israel. That mighty Prince Sampson, loved
well Honey, as appears after he had slain the Lion, he did eat the Honey
which he found in his Carcass, so did his Father, and his Mother eat of the
same Honey. It was as a divine Omen of the Wisdom and learning that afterward
came unto Plato, when in his Cradel, Bees brought Honey unto his Mouth. Who was
greater among men then S. Ihon Baptist? What was his most food? it was wild
Honey. How many pleasant verses has Virgill written upon Bees and Honey?
Plini. lib. 11. Cap. 9.
who ever did excel Plinius secundus, in the nature of Creatures, and as it
plainly appearteh in his.xj. book, he declares of a worthy man called
Aristomachus, who so wonderfully loved Bees: and in the same book, says he,
Xenophon, in his book of Household.
the Bees have many Kings with small Coronets on their heads: about whom the
great agmen or swarm does cluster and flees into the fields, and comes
home in order, bringing their treasure with them: the elder Bees do build
within the Hyues, The propertye of a good huswyfe.
having therein a Mystresse or Queen to set them to work, which never goes
from home, but places every thing in order: the younger do bring their Stuff
to the Hyue: none of them be idle, every one of them has a house to dwell
in.vj. cornered in fashion: they will suffer no filthiness to be amongst them,
nor strangers to dwell within their City or commonwealth. They also punish
them with stynginge, that hurt their Princes, Bees maintain no strangers, for
they be not profitable.
and they have fore knowledge of weather when it is fair and foul. Also they
have senses of smelling, for if any of them be lost in the field, they follow
their fellows by the sweet air, they be scant perfect of hearing* but yet as
appears they hear, when they muster at the soundes of Basens: their greatest
delight is in Time, and Balm, and therefore about Athens is the best Honey in
the World, as Plini says, and in the Islande called Calydna, Plin lib. xj
Cap. xij.
and also in Meleta: would God, says he, that we had the Honey in the same
nature that it falls from the heavens. Yea rather would to God that Idle
people would take Bees for an example to labor, and Subjects to obey* etc.
What shall I speak more of the properties of Bees, and of their good natures,
providence and cunning? nothing else Marcellus, but these simple Uerses
following. A Noble Prince there is, whose wealth and work excel,
More than all other earthly wightes, that in the world do dwell.
The king of Bees and his Army.
Saturnus black and cold, has taught him for to fly,
The hory Frostes and Snowes so white* and darkness of the Sky
Sagittarius, and Pysces, Lord Jupiter called by name,
Does cunning give unto this Prince, how he his house should fra^e.
The red and flaming bloody Mars, the Lord of war and strife,
Does teach this king his host to train, with sharp darts al their life.
O happy Sol with golden beams, whose glory does excel,
Thou art the candell of this World, and darkness do expel.
Thou make glad this little King, in fieldd when he does ride,
No Horse he has, but wings to fly, thou only art his guide,
When he does sound his warlike tune, in Hyue where he does dwell,
His Soldiers muster all on heaps, the Stars they do excel
In number infinite most fair, clear Air does them infuse,
Dame Flora sweet does them rejoice, but Boreas them misuse.
With grisly storms and Hayle so hard, he breaks their tender bones,
No helmets have, nor shieldes they bear, to keep them from hard stones.
When Storms be past and Venus come, the banisher of cold showers,
With pretty Horns, and tender wings, they play among the flowers.
The Bean flowers make them glad, the Lilly makes them gay,
Their chief delight is Time, and Balm, most glad they are of May.
For Mercury does gieue them mirth, when Twynnes he does embrace,
From rising Sun to Titans fall, labor is all their grace.
In flowred Fields and Motley meades, where white does grow in green,
The heavenly dewes, that nightly fall, is gathered up of Been.
Jove does rain from virgiliae this precious heavenly gift,
Whom Bees do know, and bear to Hyue, with Wings forth flying swyfte.
And then they make this goodly meat, Manna fallen from Heaven.
The signa.xij. with Bees do work, so do the Planets seven.



Marcellus. Now have you well declared what Honey is: is there also any virtue
in the Combs, or Wax?


Hilarious. GALEN says, in the.vj. book of Simples, Wax is good for
Plasters, not only in drying, but also in that per accidens, it moisteth, and
is used for outward Medicines, but not for inward and Dioscorides reports
that Wax does mollify and warm ye body, Dioscorides libr. secundo* Cap.
lxxvij.
and.x. graynes wayght dronken with the syrup of Pla^tein is good for the
blouddy flux: it also dries the Milk in Women's breasts: and to conclude,
there be but few Emplaysters yt can be without the help of Wax. It has also
bin abused in Churches, Chaples, and Temples, offered by the ignorant, before
the blind.


Marcellus. I do know Sage by name, because it does grow in my Garden and is
used in my Kitchen, but Christ does know, the virtue thereof is hidden from
me.


Hilarious. This noble herb is called Elclisphacon, Saluia, or Sage, Sage.
and as it should appear by Theophrastus there be two kinds of Sage, the one
of the Garden, which is rough, Lib. vj. Cap. ij. de Plan. Libr. iij. Dioscorides
long and broad leaued, which says Matthiolus, I suppose to be the Female
herb: the other Sage which is shorter, and narrower, with two small ears in
the beginning of ye leaves, which the said Theophrastus calls Sphacelo, Lib.
6. Simp.
whom Matthiolus clepeth the Male herb, and of this grows great plenty in
Italy in the tops of Mountains, in the noble Countries both of Apulia, and
Calabria: so does there almost in every Garden in England. This herb is hot
and dry, says Aetius, so says Galen, and some notable Practicioners do say,
that perfume of Sage does stop the immoderate Flux menstruall. Agrippa did
call this the hory herb, because it was so good to Women, not only in
expulsing evil matter from the Matrix, but also in retayning the vital seed
of Generation, whereby Conceptione is made perfect. The Juice of Sage helps
Conception.
If a Woman drink the Juice thereof with a little Salt, and Sugar sodden
together, four days before, and after the use with her husband, giving the
man the like quantity, before the time of procreation, without doubt Conception
follows. is said, sometime there was so great a pestilence in a City of
Egypt, that through the Poison thereof few were left a live: but when the
Plague was ceased, the young Women were compelled to drink the Wine, or Juice
of Sage, through whose virtue they were conceived with Children, having the
help of Man: that in the end, the City was replenished again, and filled
with People of their own Generation. Sage, says Orpheus..iiij. mingled with
clean clarified Honey, and eaten of an empty Stomach, To stop blood running
at ye mouth.
does incontinently stop the blood that comes from the Breast, Stomach, or
Lunges, breakinge out of the Mouth with cruent Uomites. There is a Sycknesse
within the Body, called Tabes, which is a great corruption of humors,
through foul Matter, and Blood myngled together, whose beginnynge comes
from the Head through a continual Rheum, and does Apostumate, and wound the
Lunges: through whose putrefaction by little, and little, all the Members of
the body consume, through dryness, leanness, and a continual coughe, with
pains in the Breast, An excellent Pill against Apostumatio^ of ye Lunges,
Rheum, or consumption, which helped Bullem the Aucthour of this Book.
and shortness of the Wind: the remedy there of sometime has bin with Sage
in this manner. Take Spicknard, Ginger, of each..ij. seed of Sage..viij. dried,
beaten fine in Powder, with the foresaid Spyces, and..xij. of long Peper in
like manner, and..j. of old Aster, and the Juice of Sage, and so make your Pill
in a clean Mortar, and take every Morning fasting..j. of this, and as much at
night drinkinge after it pure clean Sage water: and this is the best Pill that
ever I did know, and helped me in a great sickness in Suffolk, where
sometime I dwelled. This herb also provoke vryne, cleanses phlegm,
expulseth wind, dries up the Dropsy, helps the Paulsie, strengthens the
Sinews, To kill Canker and quench Robin good-fellowes Fever.
and purges blood: If it be sodden in running water, Roch Alum, and Woodbinde
leaves, it kills the Canker in the Mouth, and also quenches the great heat
and burninge, stynke, filthe, and matter that oftentimes comes through
corruption of nature, or meretrix manner, and does chance into the Secret
places of Men or Women, which is helped this way, puttinge in a little of the
Powder of Aristolochia rotunda: forasmutch as it dries, it is put into Pigs,
which be most moist of nature to dry up their humidity or moisture wythall,
which else be evil for Flegmatike persons. Auicen. 3. trac. cap, 1.
The incomparable virtue of this herb is excellent, that the great learned
Fathers of Salem, did write these words to the late famous Prince King Henry
the eight, in the laud thereof saying. Curmoritur homo, cui saluia crescit in
horto? Inquiringe why mortal Men should dye, which have Sage in their Gardens?
But because no herb has power to make Men immortal, they say furthermore,
Contra vim mortis, non est medicamen in hortis. And thus I do conclude of this
virtuous herb Sage. Whose Wine being daily drunk, is good against the
fallinge sycknesse. And the common Sage Ale, ryghtly brewed with Sage,
Squinance, Spicknarde, Calamus, Fenell seeds, and Betony, is very wholesome for
the Flegmaticke, Dropsy, wind Collike, and rawnesse of the stomach with
indigestion.


Marcellus. What be the virtues of Onyons in their kinds?


Hilarious. THey do make thyn the Blood, and bring sleep, they be not good
for Choleric men. Onions provoke sleep. Long Onyons.
The long Onyon is more vehemente then the round, and the Red more then the
White, the Gray more then the Green, and the raw more then the sodden, or
preserved in Salt, although they cause sleep very paynefull and troublous,
Green sickness.

To cleanse ye Stomach.


and be hot in the third degree, but they warm and cleanse the Stomach,
bring good Color to the Face, and then they must be good for the neewe
Green Sycknesse, and do very well provoke Uryne, and being roasted, and
warm applied to the Paynefull hard Emeroydes, eftesoones do open them (if
vinegar warm be put to them) and being clean pilled or taken from the over
rind and Skin, and cut of both the ends, Onions do heal the Emeroydes.
and cast into water, remaining in it one hour, and slicesed: these do take
away the vehement sharpness, that else would hurt the Eyes, and Head, For
biting of a Dog.
and being applied with Honey, Rue, and Salt, all incorporated together to the
wound bitten of a Dog, do heal it soon. Leekes purge the blood in March,
and pain the head, and be not greatly praised, for their Juice is evil,
Leekes.
says Dioscorides. The head being anointed with the Juice of them, keeps
hair from fallinge, Hair from fallinge.
there is much variety of this Onion among Writers, says Plinius, but this
shall suffice, for us Englishmen. There be great plenty of good Onions that be
brought from Flaunders, Where plenty of Onions do grow.
called saynct Homars Onions. So there be very many growing in Holland in
Lyncolneshyre, and in the Town of Duresme in the North country.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Fenell?


Hilarious. IT has power to warm in the third degree, and dry in the first,
and makes sweet the Breath: Foeniculum. Sweet breathes.

For the Eyesight.


the Seed eaten oftentimes upon an empty Stomach, does help the Eyesyght.
The Roots clean washed be very wholesome in Potage, and good in Ptisants. The
green or red tufts, growinge upon the Stalks, sodden in Wine, Potage, or
Ale, To break (...) Stone.

Increases Milk.

To wash Feet.


help the Bladder, Raynes, and break the stone, increases Milk in Women's
Breasts, and Seed of Generation. It is good to use Endyue, or such like with
it, because it is very hoate, and it is very good to wash ones Feet to
bedwarde. It is good in Barbars Bathes, and washinge Water, with Balm, and
Bays. The syrup is very good and wholesome, An excellent medicine of Fenel,
for the Raynes and Bladder.
it helps a Flegmatike Stomach. And Fenell, Parsely, and Watercresses, of
each like quantity stamped together, pouring white Wine to them, and the crummes
of Barley bread, standinge all one night in a stone Mortar, the next day being
strayned, Clarifyed, and drunk, this will cleanse the Raynes from Gravel,
Stone, and Choler, For fat folks.
and cause one to make much Water that has the Strangury. Two kinds of Fenell.
It is good for fat Men to open the vessels, as Uaynes, and Guts. There be
two kinds of Fenell, one Marathrum, which is best: the other Hippomarathrum
which is Wild, the Seed has greater virtue then the root.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Purslan?


Hilarious* Cold in the third, and moist in the second degree. Purslan is an
herb of a singular virtue to cool, or quench Choler.
If it be stamped with steeped Barley, it makes a good plaster to cool the
Head, Eyes, and Liver, in Agues, and hoate infla^mations. To eat of it,
stops fluxes, and quenches burning Choler, extinguisheth venereous lust,
and greatly helps ye Raynes, and Bladder, and will kill round Worms in the
Belly: and comfort the matrixe, against hoate choler, and terms abounding.
And the juice is good to drink in hot Fevers: it may be preserved with Salt,
and then it is very good with roasted meats. Plini says, it is supposed to
make the sight blunt and weak: An example of Purslan.
Further he says that in Spain, a great noble man, whom he did know, did hang
this Purslane root on a Thread, commonly about his neck, which was troubled of
a Vuula, and was healed therewith.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Dragons?


Hilarious. THe juice of Dragons, says Dioscorides, dropped into ye eyes, does
cleanse them, Of Dragons which help against the Pestilence.
and causes mutch brightness unto the eyes of them, which have dark sights.
The Water of this herb, has virtue against the pestilence, if it be drunk
blood warm with Uenice Triacle, or Mithridatum. The savor of this herb is
hurtefull to women newly conceived with Child. Plini says, that who so
bears this herb upon them, no venomous Serpent will do them any harm. This
herb is hoate and dry, and being sodden in Wine, it heals a kibed heel,
called Pernio. And this herb being bruised, and applied with Plantein, heals
a new wound.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Filipendula?


Hilarious. Filipendula has round roots hanging upon small fine thredes in the
earth.
IT is called Filipendula, because it has small round roots, hanging upon it
with thredes in the ground, it is an herb hoate and dry, in the third degree:
if it be sodden in white wine, and dronk, it dries up windy places in the
guts, and cleanses the raines of the back and bladder. And the powder drunk
in Wine, is good against the falling evil, and helps the yellow Iaundice:
the leaves and stalks sodden in Wine and drunk, cleanse the secondes.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Violettes?


Hilarious. SIMEON SETHI reports, that they do help against hoate
inflammations of the Guts, Uiolets be great coolers and to cold for the
heart.
head, and stomach, if the cause be of burninge Choler: either the Water,
Sirup, or Conserve of the said Uiolets, being eaten or drunk, after the
digestion of any hoate passion: but undoubtedly it offends the heart, because
of ye great coldness. The sauoure of the Flowers be pleasant. The Oil that is
made of this herb, has virtue to reconcile quiet sleep to them, which have
grievous hoate pain in the head, Good for Coughes and shortwinde.
Uiolet water, and clean Sallet Oil, of each one ounce together drunk,
cleanses rotten matter in the Stomach, and Coughes, or pain in the Lunges.


Marcellus What is the virtue of white Lillies, and water Lillies called
Nimphea.


Hilarious. DIoscorides says, that the Oil of Lillies does mollifye the
Sinews, and the mouth of the matrix: ye Juice of Lillies, Uineger, and Honey,
sodden in a Brazen vessel, does make an ointment, to heal both new and old
wounds: if the Roots be roasted, and stamped with Roses, they make an healing
plaster against burning of fire: the same root Roasted, has virtue to break a
pestilence sore, applied hot unto the sore place, and is dry in the first
degree. The oil of Water Lillies, is moist, sovereign against all hot
diseases to anoint the ardent and hot places, and does reconcile quiet sleep,
if the forehed be anointed therewith it is wholesome for mad men. The seed and
root sodden in wine, stops the immoderate flux menstruall, and the bloody
Flixe, as Dioscorides and Galen say Libro viij Simplicium Medicamento^um.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Chickweede?


Hilarious. ALmost every ignorant woman does know this herb, but there be of
diverse kinds of it, Anagallis o^ morsus Gallinae, called Chickweede.
they be very good to keep wounds from apostumations, stamped, and applied
unto them, and draw corruption out of wounds: and sodden with Uineger, do
draw fleume out of the head if Chickweede be often warm, put into the
mouth, and spit out again, in the same manner it helps the teeth, and sodden
in wine, and so drunk, it will cleanse the raynes of the back.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Sorel, which in the North is called Sower
Dockes.


Hilarious. Every one does right well know it, and al they that make greensauce,
but the description, I leave to Dioscorides, Rumex, ^apathus, or acedu is
Sorel, an Sor^ll de bois.
and Leonardus Fuchsius, not only in this herb, but in all other, and to tell
the virtue I will: it is cold and dry, in the second degree, it also stops:
it is like Endive in property, because it overcomes Choler, and is much
commended. It helps the yellow Iaundice, if it be drunk with small wine or
ale, and also quenches burning fevers: to eat of the leaves every Morninge
in a Pestilence time, is most wholesome, if they be eaten fasting. This herb
does Dioscorides, Galen and Auicen greatly commend, besides the great learned
men of this time.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Planten or VVaybrede?


Hilarious. THe greatter Planten is the better, it has seven great veins, it
is cold and dry: Plantago called arnoglosia.
the seeds drunk with red wine, or the roots sodden therein, stop the
bloody flux, likewise the roots and leaves being sodden with fair water, or
with Burrage water and Sugar, and given to him yt has an Ague, either Tertian
or quarten, two hours before his fit, helps him. Prove this, for thus have
I helped many, it is very comfortable for children that have great fluxes
and Agues, and is a friend unto the Liver. This herb is greatly praised of the
learned writers. Water Planten roots, leaves and buddes be wholesome to be dronk
against the falling sickness.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Camomill?


Hilarious. THis herb is very hot, it is drunk against cold winds, and
matter being in the guts, the Egiptians did suppose it would help all cold
Agues, and did consecrate the same as Galen says: also if it be tempered and
strayned into white wine, and drunk of women having the child dead within
their bodies, it will cause present deliverance: it does mightily cleanse the
bladder, and is excellent to be sodden in water to to wash the feet, the Oil
is precious, as is declared hereafter.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Hoppes?


Hilarious. THere be Hoppes which do cool, that be called Lupuli: those that we
have be hoate and dry, Lupulus Salictarius, be ^oppes
bitter, sower, hot, says old Herballes, and Fuchsius says, they cleanse
Fleume, and Choler, and the Water between the skin and Flesh. The syrup will
cleanse gross raw Fleume from the guts, and is good against obstructions. If
the Juice be dropped in the Ear, it takes away the stink of Rotten Sores,
the roots will help the Liver, and Spleen, being sodden and drunk, the Beer
is very good for Flegmatike men.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Horehounde?


Hilarious. IT is an herb hoate and dry, if it be sodden with fair water,
Sugar or Honey, and strayned, this drink does cleanse the stomach from stinking
fleume. It is an excelent herb for women to cleanse their Monthly terms.
Stinkinge fleume.
The water of this, is good to help them which have a moist Reume falling from
the head upon the Lunges, being often drunk, To help a moist reume.
but it is hurtful to the bladder and raynes, the syrup thereof does cleanse the
kings evil. And also put into the ears it does greatly comfort the hearing,
if ye ears be troubled with deafnes: stamped with honny and applied to the
eyes, it cleanses the sight. Kings evil.
To help the sight.

or pain in the throat.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Rice? Rice.



Hilarious. There be many opinions concerning Rice, Auice^, in ij. can. Cap*
78.
but I shall stay my self with the Judgments of Auicen. Rice says he, is
hot and dry, and has virtue to stop the Belly, it does nourish much, ^it
be sodden with Milk, qut it ought to be stepped in water an whole night
before. If Blaunched Almons be stamped with Rose water, and strayned into
them, and sodden with Cowes milk, it is very much nourishinge: the Flower or
Meal of Arza or Rise, stops the bloudye flyxe, in drink or Clister.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Pease and Beans* Beans*



Hilarious. Beans be more grosser and fuller of wynd, then Pease be, and make
evil matter, except they be well sodden and buttered, and so eaten with the
whitest Onions that may be gotten, because they be hard of digestion: how be it
they do make fat, and partly cleanse, To make fat.
yet they are not compared with tender white Peason, well sodden and buttered,
or else made in pottage with garden Mintes, and gross Pepper which have virtue
to cleanse the raynes of the Back and bladder, There is a place in Suffolk
called Orfort, where Pease grow on the stones, never sown. Lintelles be of the
same virtue. Barley being clean hulled, and sodden with milk, clean water
and Sugar, makes a very wholesome and comfortable potage, for whole Choleric
persons, or young people, and this is much used in the North parts of England
and is called Big Keale, and of clean Barley and pure water, Ptisant.
is made that excellent water. called Ptisant.


Marcellus. Beats.
What is the virtue of Beetes.


Hilarious. White beetes
THere be of two kinds, and both be praise worthy. Simeon Sethi writes, that
they be hot and dry in the third degree, the white be the best, Purging the
head.
they have virtue to cleanse, as Niter has but are of evil juice: ye juice of
this herb with Honny, applied into the Nose, do purge the head, so does the
leaf, it is an holsom herb in pottage, if it be well sodden, or else noisome to
the stomach, if it be parboyled and eaten with Uineger, it is good against the
stopping of the liver, Stoppinge of the Liver.
not withstandinge the juice of this herb does stop the belly being symplie
taken. It is called Beat of Beta, or Ueta the Greek. B. because of the form
or shape.


Marcellus. Betony.
What is the virtue of Betony?


Hilarious. THey be of diverse kinds Leonardus Fuchsius, does call the sweet
Giloflowers by the names of Betonye, but he seems to talk of that which is
commonly known of the people, To kill worms,
called the land Betony, which has virtue to kill worms within the belly, and
helps the Quarten, cleanses the Matrix, For Bruses.
and has virtue to heal the Body within if it be bruised: it is of so great
effect, if it be sodden with Wormwood in white wine, as to purge Fleume, it is
hot in the first degree, and dry in the second.


Marcellus. Sauery.
What is the virtue of Sauerie?


Hilarious. IT is hoate and dry in the third degree, if the green Herb be
sodden in water or white wine, Liver soft. Cold coughs. Dead children.
and drunk, these be his virtues: to make the Liver so it, to cleanse Dropsies,
cold Coughes, to cleanse women's diseases, and to separate the dead child from
the mother, as Dioscorides and Galen say: also Germander is not much unlike in
virtue to this herb.


Marcellus. Mustarde.
What is the virtue of Mustard or Sinapium.


Hilarious. PLINIVS does greatly allow it, saying, that there is nothing does
pierce more swifter into the brain then it does. Honye Vinegar, To Gargarize
the head.
and Mustarde tempered together, is an excellent Gargarisme to purge the head,
teeth, and throat. Mustarde is good against all the diseases of the stomach, or
Lunges, wind, fleume and rawnesse of the guts, and conduces food into the
body, Fallinge sickness. Palsy.
provoke urine, helps the Palsy, wastes the qua^ten, dries. up moist
reumes, applied playsterwise unto the head. Honye and Mustarde helps the
coughe, and is good for them that have the Falling sycknesse: And tents of
Vinegar and Mustard put into the nose help the Palsye. Notwithstanding the
common use of Mustarde, Evil for the eyes.
is a cruel enemy unto ye eyes: many more virtues have I read of Mustarde, but
the occasion of time has unhappily prevented, not only my large description
in this, but also in many other Simples.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Senetion or Groundesyll? Senetion.



Hilarious. IT is of a mixed temperature, it cools and partly cleanses. If it
be stamped and sodden in water, and drunk with your Pottage, Hot Collar in ye
stomach* To help the eyes.
it will purge hot Choler: this done with Saffron and cold water, stamped and
put into the eyes, it will dry the runninge drops of them: and prepared ^laster
wise, it helps many grievous wounds. Dioscorides says, that the heads of
Senetion with the flowers, and a little wine and Manna, Dioscorides lib iiij.
cap. xcij.

For wounds


tempered together, heals the wounds, that be in the synewes. The flower of
this herb, has white hair, and when the wind blows it away, then it
appears like a Balde headded Man, therefore it is called Senecio.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Cucummers* Cucummers?



Hilarious. THey be (truly) in the second degree very moist, and cold the
Seeds be very good to be given in hot sicknesses. The powder of the same
Seeds drunk in clean Wine, are good against diverse hoate passions of the
Heart, To provoke vryne,

Uomit.

Good blood.


This Fruit will cause one to make water well. The root dried, and the powder
thereof drunk in water and Honye, provoke vomit. If they be moderatly eaten,
they bring good blood. Tempered with Honye, Epinictides*
and the Eyes there with anointed they help a disease called Epinictidas,
which troubles men with strange syghtes in the Night: the best of this fruit
is yt which bears ye best seed ye savor of them is holsom. Melons, citruls,
Pompeions, Raw herbs*
and this kind of Pepins, or great Apples, be much used in England, and are
more common the^ profitable, because they use to eat the^ raw, Englishmen being
born in a te^perat region, enclyning to cold, may not without hurt eat raw
herbs, roots, and fruits so plentiful, as many men which be borne far in the
South parts of the world, which be most hoate of stomach: therefore eat
these fruits boiled, orels baked with Honey, Peper, and Fenell seeds, or such
like: there be an other hot kind of bitter Cucummers, which do purge called
Colocynthis. The Apple being steeped in Ptisant water, duringe Twelve hours,
and so strayned, and drunk in the Morninge half a pint, does purge
Melancholy, and Choler adust and vitriall fleume, but it is a very gross
purgation, but ye Trochiskes of Coloquintida are better to purge with.
Coloquitide*
But.i of the Powder of Coloquintida sodden with Mirthe and Ote water, and
Honye to a thicknes, makes a goodly Pil to purge Fleume and choler, it is
good in Clisters, Dioscorides. lib. iiij. capit. Clxx.
for the same purpose, sodden with vinegar, this kept in the mouth, kills
worms in the teeth. The Oil of this is good to anoint the pains of the Huckel
bone called Sciattica, It also kills worms in the Ears: this is most
bitter to the mouth and stomach, it kills worms in the Belly, Matthiolus
super dioscoride^.
both in Emplasters and drink. The Arabians call this herb Chandel, but in
Laten it is called Cucurbita Syluestris.


Marcellus. Cabage.
What is the virtue of Cabage or Brassica?


Hilarious. CAbage is of two properties, of byndinge the Bellye, and making
laxatiue, Ius Brassicae soluit, cuius substantia stringit.

To bind laxatiue

To cleanse Leprosy.

Aristote.iij. probl. Auicen.ii. ca^Rasisiij. Al.


the juice of Cabages, lightlye boiled in fresh Beef brothe is laxatiue, but
the substance of this herb is hard of digestion, but if it be sodden twyse,
the broth of it will bind the Belly, if it be tempered with Allume: This herb
has virtue to cleanse a new Red Leprosye, laid upon the sore place, in the
manner of a Plaster, but to conclude of this herb, ye broth of it has virtue
to keep a man from drunkenness, as Aristotle, Rasis, and Auicen do report,
eaten before meat or drink. And this is good to make Pottage withal, and is
a profitable herb in a common wealth, which the Fleminges sell dear, but we
have it growing in our own Gardens, Dioscor. li. 4.
if we would prefer our own commodity, before ydlenes, and not suffer weeds
to grow where herbs should be planted. If Fenegrike and this be sodden
plaster wise, it helps the Gout, The leaves sodden with Honye, heal ulcers
and Cankers, and kill worms in the Bellye, there be sundry kinds of wortes,
both Garden, Feelde and Sea, mutche like to each other in virtue. There be
great plenty growing between Albrought and Horthforde in Suffolk upon ye Sea
shore.


Marcellus. Rue called Herb grace.
What is the virtue of Rue, or herb of Grace?


Hilarious. I Tell thee this herb* is very hot and bitter, and does burn,
because of his hotenes in the third degree. If a little of this Rue be stamped,
and sodden in wine, and drunk, it is an excellent medicine against Poison and
Pestilence. Roses, Uineger and Riue stamped together, Poison Pain in the head.
and put into a Forhead cloth or Bigge^ and applied to the Temples of the
head, or Forehead, do cease grievous pain in the head. And in like manner it
helps the bytinge of Serpents, and of Dogs, stamped with vinegar, many nice
people cannot abide it, cryinge fie it stinks. The sede of this herb beaten in
powder and put in fresh clarifyed Butter, Against biting of Dogs and serpe^ts.
and Pitche melted together, is good for them to drink that are bruised The
seed of this Rue being dried and beaten into powder, with ye pouders of sweet
Calamus and long Pepper sodden in white Wine, drunk warm helps the wind in
the small Guts. Buleins experience many times.



Marcellus. What is the virtue of Lettice Lettice.



Hilarious. IT does mightily increase Milk in women's breasts, To increase Milk
and therefore it is called Lettice, as Martial says, first shall be given to
the virtue and power, to increase milk in women's breasts every hour. Comfort
against hoate cholic^ in the stomach.
Lettice is an herb cold and moist and very comfortable for a hot stomach,
brings sleep, mollifyeth the bellye, the dryer it be eaten the better it is.
I mean, if it be not much washed in water, adding clean Salet Oil, Sugar
and vinegar to it, it abateth carnal lust: and much use of it dulleth the
sight. Ill forsight. To abate the Lust.

An increase of seed.

Broke bones Coughe.

Dioscor. lib* ij* Cap. cxxxliij.


The seed is precious against hot diseases, drunk with Ptisantes. There is
an herb called Rocket gentle, that partly smells like a Fox, which is very
hot, an encreaser of seed, this herb must always be eaten with Lettice. The
root thereof sodden in water will draw forth broken bones, and will help the
cough in young children, the seed does vehemently expel vryne, drunk in
white wine, and kills woormes: and tempered with an Ox gaul, does cleanse
black spots in the face or skin after strypes.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Mintes? Mintes



Hilarious. MIntes be of two kinds, garden and wild Mintes, Stoppinge of vomits.

Repletion.

To kill worms.

Bytinge of a Dog.

To help the Collike.


they be hot unto the third degree, and dry in the second degree Garden
Mintes be best: the powder of this with the juice of Pomgranets, stops
vomits, helps sighing, cleanses hot choler. Three branches of this sodden
with wine does help repleation, being drunk fasting. This juice tempered
with good Triakle, and eaten of children in morninges, will kill worms, and

ye powder of Mints are good in pottage to help digestio^, and to make sweet

the^ belly.
with Roses and Uineger te^pered together, it helps the head in hot

Burning Agues.


and defends the head from hot smoking vapoures, and purges yellow choler,

Marcellus. Hysop.
What is the virtue of Hysope?


Hilarious. AN herb commonly known, growing in gardens, and hot in the third
degrre: it has virtue to make humors thin and warm: Dioscor lib. 3.
sodden with Figs, Rewe, and Honey, in clean water, and drunk, greatly
helps the sickness in the lungs old Coughes, Sickness in the Lunges. Old
coughes, Rotten humors.

To help the Spleen.


rotten humors, drippinges upon the lunges, sodden with Eris, and Graynes of
Paradise called Cardamomu^, it mightily purges and brings good color.
Figs, Salt Nitrum, and Hysope stamped together, and applied to the Spleen,
help it much, and take awoy the water that runs between the skin and the
Flesh: sodden with Oximel it cleanses flewme. How be it, Galen writes but
little of this herb in his eight book of Simples, Fleume.
but says that it is dry and hot in the third degree. But this herb was
used in the old Testament, in the old time of the bloody Sacrifice. And the
