Marcellus. What say you of Lapis Magne?


Hilarious The magnet stone.
THe best is that which will draw Iron or Ste^le to him: given three half penny
weight in powder tempered with sweet water, it will cast forth fylth and
groose matter out of the body. Pliny shows. lib. xxxiiii. Cap. xiiij. that
one builded a Temple, covered with this Magnes stone, wherein his Image with
pomp was brought in, which was made of Iron, which ascended by attraction, and
did hang in the roffe; his name was Arsion. The Arabians and Mahumetans did in
like case bring in the steel Toumbe of master Mahumet (their iuglyng false
Prophet) into a Temple of Magnes stones, whose nature was to draw the said
Toumb up. But the best service that the Magnes does, is in the Ship, for the
compass of sailing in true setting the needle. Also in plasters the powder
thereof to draw forth Iron or pricks from the flesh.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of the flesh of Oxen, Steeres or Bulls, and
Calves.


Hilarious I Will not undertake to show mine opinion at your request only, but I
will also declare the mynds of some wise and learned men: and first of Simeon
Sethi, who says that the flesh of Oxen, Of the flesh of Oxen, steres, Bulls,
and Calves.
that be young does mutch nourish and make them strong that be sed with Beef,
but it breeds choler adust, and melancholious diseases, it is cold and dry
of nature, and hard to digest, except it be eaten of chollericke persons, but
being tenderly sodden, Beef good for the cholorike, but evil for tender
stomachs.
it nourysheth mutch: Beef customably eaten of idell persons, and nice folk
that labor not, brings many diseases, as Rasis says: and Auicen says, that
the flesh of Oxen, or Kine, be very gross, ingendryng ill Juice in the Body,
whereof oftentime come scabs, Cankers, and Biles: but unto hot strong
chollerike stomachs, it is tolerable and may be used as we have the daily
experience thereof. The broth wherein the Beef has been sodden, Beef broth
against the flixe.
is good to be supped or drunk half a pynte every morning against the flix of
the belly, and running forth of yellow choler, if the said broth be tempered
with Salt, Mustarde, Vinegar, or Garlike, commonly used for sauces to digeste
the said Beef with all: for the said sauces do not only help digestion, but
also defend the body from sundry inconveniences, and diverse sycknesses, as
Dropsies, Quartens, Leprosies, and such like. The Gaul of an Ox, or a Cow
distilled in the Month of June, and kept in a close Glass, Ox Gaul cleanse
the eyes
does help to cleanse the eyes from spots, if you put a drop of this water
with a fether into the eyes when ye go to bed: the Milte of a Bull dried, and
the powder thereof drunk with Red wine, will stop the bloody flixe: Ox Mylte
stop the flixe.
light poudred young Beef is better: than either fresh or mutch poudred* in
specially of those cattle that be fed in fair and dry pastures, and not in
stynking Fens. the great learned man Gesnerus in his description of beasts,
does write more of the virtues of Bulls, Oxen, Kine, and Calves, Gesnerus
writes mutch of breasts, the male better then the female.
than any other has don and thus to conclude, the flesh of the Male beasts, is
more better than of the female, and the gelded beasts, be more commodious to
nature than any of them, and the young flesh more commendable than the old,
for it is moyster, and a friend to the blood. Haliabas says, roasted flesh
does greatly nourysh the body, for it is warm and moist: baked meats be very
dry: clean boiled meats with wholesome herbs, and fruicts. be excellent in
virtue to comfort the body if they be nutrimental flesh. Calves flesh the
profit thereof.
Calves flesh does greatly increase nourish, and make good blood. Specially
the brawne or Muskels of the thigh, are best, says Master Conrade Gesner, and
further says he, if a man be wounded, then lay Calves flesh newly slain to it,
and this will defend the wound from apost^macion or swelling: and sodden in
vinegar, and warm applied to any part, as armeholes, Against Ramishnes under
ye arms.
breast of them that stink like a Ram or Goat, it will take away the said
stynke: also it helps the bityng of a Man or a mad Dog, so that this flesh
remain upon the said wound, during five days, and v. nights close and not
taken away. Celsus for a vomitte.


Celsus in his medicines against the biting of Serpents, if nothing can suck
it forth by medicine or boxing, says he, then drink the broth wherein Geese
or Ueale has been sodden, and then provoke vomit.

Great is the goodness of this flesh, both in meat and medicine. Take the
knuckel or sinew part of a Calfe, sees it in Wine and water, puttyng in Dates,
Prunes, Reisynges of the Sun, grated bread, Maces, Cloves* Fenell roots,
Liuerwort, Planten, Purs^en, fresh Capers, Borage, and Rosemarie flowers,
sodden all together in a silver, iron, or stone pot, close boiled that no air
can go forth. You may put in half a Cock: this flesh and broth gives health
to them that are in consumption, weak bodies, or them which be evil
complexioned, or cold of nature. overcome by Melancholy. etc.


Marcellus. What is the goodness of Porke, or of gelded swine, Pigges, and Bores
flesh. etc.


Hilarious Porke the commendacion thereof.
MOst of the ancient, and wisest Phisicions that ever were in this world, did
consent, that of all flesh, the flesh of young gelded swyne, partly salted or
poudered, was ever meat of the best nourishing, moyster, and colder than other
flesh. For Isaac says, it is a flesh most moist, except it be the flesh of
Lambs. as Galen reports: yet it is not good for every complexion, nor to
every age, but unto youth and myddle age. And whereas Almighty God, did
prohibit the Jews to eat. swynes flesh: it was a figure to abstain from
unclean things, which I leave to the divines. The Mahumites abhor swynes
flesh, because their drunken false Prophet and Pseudo Apostle was torn, and
rent in pieces with Hogs: Swines blood.
being drunken and fallen into the mire: and now we must give credence to time,
and to learned Phisicions. The Blood of Swine does nourish mutch, as is seen
in Puddinges, made with great Otemeale, Pigges
Peper, sweet suet, and Fenell, or Anisseedes. Young Pigges be very moist,
therefore Sage. Peper and Salt does dry up the superfluous humors of them when
they be roasted. Tripes.
They be not wholesome to be eaten, before they be three-weekes old: Bacon.
the Trypes and Guts be wholsomer, and do nourysh better, than any other
beasts Gutts. Bacon is very hard of digestion, and mutch discommended of some
men. and is hurtful only unto a hot Chol^rike labouryng body* but a tender
gammon of Bacon is tolerable, and very good flesh with wine as custom does
prove it.

Swine of Inde have horns.
Agatharsides says, that the swyne in Aethiopia have horns growyng upon
their heads, there be diverse kynds of swyne, both wyld, and tame: whose inward
parts, be not mutch unlike unto mankind, and for that Galen began to make
Anatomies of them, in the beginning of his practice, teaching the Chirurgians
to do the like. Why hogs are diseased.
These kind of beasts do hear very easily, and be given mutch to sleep, and
will eat their own Pigges, and feed upon most vile things: for which cause
they have most vile diseases, as Angina in the throat* sores, botches, and
byles. If they be letten blood in the vein under the tongue, and Madder be
given them and an herb called Pancis, otherwise named in Latin herba
Trinitatis, it helps them, if it be sodden in Whey. Those swine that use to
feed by the sea side. and eat of young Crabs, be delivered of many diseases:
if they do feed upon Polipodie, they shall be delivered of the Pestilence.
Among the Christen Men, Bores flesh is had in great estimacion, to be eaten in
Winter: and chiefly upon Chrystmas day. Galen does greatly commend the same
flesh, or Braune, to be eaten in winter: and also this Bores flesh is proved in
the time of Pestilence, to break a plague sore. Bores grease, and his stones,
or any part of them stamped together and warm applied to the same sore,
works that effect. And thus I do end of Swyne, which in their lives be most
vile, noisome, and never good until they die.


Marcellus. What is the virtues of Lambs, and Weathers flesh?


Hilarious. SImeon Sethi says, Lambs flesh is partly warm, Lambs flesh good
roasted. evil sodden.
but superfluous moist, and evil for flegmatike persons, and does mutch
harm to them that have the Dropsy, boneach, or a disease called Epialus,
which is spitting of phlegm, shyning like Glass. Therefore, if Lambs flesh
were sodden, as it is roasted, it would bring many dyseases unto the bodies of
them, without it were sodden in wine, and some hoate Grosseries, herbs, or
roots. When a Weather is two year old, which is fed upon a good Ground, the
flesh thereof shall b^e temperate, and nourishes mutch. Hippocrates says,
that the Lamb of a year old, does nouryshe mutch. Galen seems not greatly to
commend Mutton, but that which is tender, sweet, and not old, is very
profitable, Mutton.
as experience and custom do daily teach us. The doung, Tallow, and UUolle,
be very profitable in medicines, as Pliny says, and Conradus Gesnerus, de
animalibus* and Galen in his third book de Alementis,


Marcellus. UUhat be the virtues of Goats, or Kiddes flesh?


Hilarious. THese be beasts very hurtful unto young trees and plants but Simeon
Sethi says, Kiddes flesh very good.
that Kiddes flesh is easy of digestion, in health and sickness, they be very
good meat, they be very dry of nature. Hippocrates says, it behooves that ye
conseruers and kepers of health, should study that their meat be such as the
flesh of Kiddes, Flesh good for sick persons.
young calves that be sucking, and lambs of one year old, for they be good
for them that be sick, or have evil complexion. Haliabbas says, that the
flesh of Kids, does engender good blood, and is not so flegmatike, waterie and
moist, as the flesh of Lambs: they remain Kiddes for six months, and
afterward come into grosser, and hoatex nature, and then be called Goats: the
flesh of them that be gelded are wholesome to eat, The lunges of them eaten
before a man does drink, does defend him that day from drunkenes, Goats flesh.
as I have heard, by the reports of learned men: but the flesh of old male
Goats is evil, and engenders Agues, or Fevers. Conradus. Gesnerus de
animalibus Matthiolus super Diolco.
If the Uriue of Goats be distilled in May, with Sorel the water distilled is
not hurtful nor noisome* but whosoever uses to drink thereof..ii. morning and
evening, it will preserve him from the Pestilence. The Milk of Goats I will
describe in the proper place.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Red, and fallow Dear:


Hilarious. Dear red and fallow* be spoylers of Corn.
THey are more pleasant to some, than profitable to many as appears once a
year in the corn fields, the more it is to be lamented. Hippocrates, and
Simeon Sethi do plainly affirm that ye flesh of them does engender evil juice,
and Melancholy, cold diseases, The winter Dear better then the summer.
and Quarte^s: the flesh of winter Dear, does less hurt the body. than that
which is eaten in Summer, for in winter man's digestion is more stronger, and
the inward parts of the body warmer, and may easelier consume gross meats,
than in summer, as we see by experience, in cold weather and frostes,
healthful people be most hungrest. The lunges of a Dear sodden in Barley
water, and stamped with Penidies, and Honey, of equal quantity, The lunges o^
the Dear.
to the said lunges, and eaten a Morninges does greatly help the old coughes,
and dryness in the Lunges: there be many goodlye virtues of their Horns,
bones, blood, and tallow. Look Conradus Gesnerus de animalibus.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Hares and Conies?


Hilarious. Of Hares flesh and Conies.
AVICEN says, the flesh of Hares, is hot and dry, an engenderer of
Melancholy, not praised in Physic for meat, but rather for medicine: for in
deed if a Hare be dried in ye month of March, in a Oven or Furnice and beaten
into powder, and kept close, and drunk mornings in Bear, Ale, or white wine,
it will break the stone in the Bladder, if the pacyente be not old: The powder
of the Hare, for the stone.
if chyldrens gummes be anointed with the brains of an Hare, their teeth will
easily come, and grow. The gaul of an Hare mingled with clean Honey, does
cleanse watery eyes, or red bloody eyes. The flesh of Hares must be tenderly
roosted and well larded, and spyced. because of the grosenes, but it is better
sodden. The flesh of Conies, is better than Hares flesh, and easyer of
digestion, but Rabets be wholesome, for meat of sick people: and thus to
conclude of Conies, experience teaches us, that they are good: they be cold
and dry of nature, and small mention is made of them among the ancient
Phisicions, Galeni de simp. medica.
as Galen says. I need not to speak very long of every kind of beasts, as
some of the beasts that be in Hiberia, like little Hares which be called Conies.


Marcellus. What is the nature of a beast called Erinaceus, called the
Porpentine, and Echinus called the Hedghog, which is full of pryckes?


Hilarious. DIOSCORIDES lib. 2. cap. 2. says, the skins of them combust or
burnt, and beaten in fine powder, Erinaceus or Porpentine for baldness* to
increase hair.
and tempered with Tar, is a good ointment for to increase hair, and keep of
baldness. The dried flesh of them sodden in Uineger and Sugar, is good to be
drunk against the stoppyng of the raynes, conuulsions, Leprosies of phlegm, or
an evil complexion. The powder of this Porpe^tine must be kept close in a
vessel for medycine. The powder of the Hare which is dried in March, Hares
powder for the Raynes.
must be used for the purging of the Raynes, and clensyng of the bladder, ye
said powder is to be drunk with white wine, and Cassiafistula. Also the
grease of the Propentine, or Hedghogge, with Bears grease and Laudanum,
ana..i. beaten in a Leaden mortar, this is a good ointment against baldness or
loss of hair, to rub the place daily therewyth The Livers of Porpentines
dried and beaten into powder are good for the Raines, or Morbus Elephantiacus.
Tese beasts be of cold nature. better for medicine than meat. and be vermen
or beasts of the night, armed against Dogs, with long pricks, and headed
mutch like a Hare, with teeth according, and ears like an Ape. etc. The Urchin
or Hedghogge is commonly known, and headded like a Swine or young Pigge. The
powder of them as Pliny affyrmeth, being drunk, will help and defend the
consumption: and thus I do end of this beast called Echinus, which the
Arabians call Caufed. The Urchin or Hedghog.
The Urchin of the the Sea is good for the belly, stomach and vryne.
Dioscorides lib 2. cap. 1.


Marcellus. uWhat say you of the Fiber, Beuer, or Castor?


Hilarious THis Castor lives by water and land, he loves to feed upon Crabs
and Cankers of the Sea. Castor or Beuer.
The stones of a Castor are a warm medicine, and prevail against poison, to
be drunk or in ointment. And the powder of ye same stones be good to move
sternutation or neesyng, blowe^ into the noose Of the powder..ii. with
Penyroyall, called Pulial. ii.ss te^pered together in wine and drunk, will
cause a woman in her travel soon to be delivered, and the seconds to follow,
and finally to cleanse the body, and helps swellings, collickes Iliaces,
syghinges, Cordiaces, Lytharges and poison drunk with Uineger: and in fine it
is so warm, that it helps all the passions or sickenesses in the breast,
belly, liver, and sinews, Castor stones do help all cold infirmites both in
men and women
coming of cold: the Beuer stones be best, that be most grave and strong of
savor and have a liquor mutch like Cerase within the Cod, and covered with a
natural coueryng. Pliny. xxxij. cap. iij. Castor is good to help the
Comitiall or falling sickness, to be drunk. The Oil of them is also good for
the Teeth, raynes. belly, breast, and to be dropped into the Ears.


Marcellus. What say you of the little beast Mustela. called the Weesell or
Wezell, which is commonly known?


Hilarious. This Mustela called the Weesel, is commonly known: and this Weesel,
the flesh thereof sodden in Wine and drunk, The Weesel is good against the
falling sikenes and Struma. Angina or swelling of the throat.
is a present remedy against all venim, poison, and the Falling Sickness.
with Uineger the grease of the Weesel sodden, is a goodly medicine to anoint
the Gout with all. The Blood of Weesels is good to anoynte the Necks.
Throats, and stomachs of them which have Struma, that is, the swelling of the
Throat or the Falling sycknesse, or Palsy. The donge of the Weesell with
Honey, Fenigreeke, and Lupines beaten together, is good to anoint warm the
throat, for the sycknesse called Struma: the gaul of the weesel tempered with
the water of Fenell, is a present remedy for the dimnesse of the eye, to be put
therein: and all the spots as Morphew of the skin, is cleansed therewyth. The
Lunges of the Weesell is good in powder, For to heal ye Morphew.
to be drunk against all the infirmities of the Lunges, with many other Uertues
of the Weesell, and properties, as to kyl Mise and Rattes, to serve in the
house like Cattes, but the savor of the said Weesel is mortiferous and
deadly. Pliny lib. 8. cap. 22.


Marcellus. What say you of Raynard the Fox, and the Bear?


Hilarious. THe Lunges of the Fox is good in Medicine, for the sick Lunges of
mankind. The Fox the Bear the Badgarde.
The grease of the Fox is also good for all Coldness, Palsy, and the
contraction of the sinews, and tremblyng of the body. The Bear is a beast
whose flesh is good for mankind: To help baldness.
his fat is good with Laudanum, to make an ointment to heal balde headded men
to receive the hair again. The grease of the Bear, the fat of a Lamb, and
the ointment of the Fox, makes a good ointment to anoint the feet against the
pain of travel or labor of footmen. Bear, Fox, and Brocke are good to
help the Palsy.
All the parts of the Fox, the Badgar, and the Bear are good in medicine, or
meat against the Palsy, tremblyng or coldness of the flesh, or any of them.
There is a common fable among the people, that is to say a Bear has a
disformed Whelp in the time of delyueraunce, without Members, which is not
true: for the Bear in the birth has all the members, as other beasts have.
Read Matthiolus in Dioscorides lib. iii. cap. supra.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of a Bird, called the Osspraye.


Hilarious Haleetus the Ospray a water Egle.
LIke as the Egle, and all kinds of Hawks, do pray and feed upon the flesh
of birds: even so God has ordained ye water Egle, called Haliaeetus the
Osspraie, to fear the Fishes, and feed upon them. And all Hawks, or Birds of
the Nature of Egles, with hard crooked bills, are compted unclean flesh.
Leui. xi. are not used common among us, unto this day. Ospraies oil good to
put in water to gather fi^h ready to be taken.
Howbeit, the Oil or grease of the Osspraie, is had in great estimacion to
take Fish withal: and the head thereof dried and beaten into powder, makes a
good medicine for young infant children, to be put into the Nosthrilles, to
break wind very gentle. And the Gaul is wholesome for sore eyes to be dropped
with the white of an Egg into them. And the geease and Gaul, Medicines made
of the Ospray.
will heal the stinginge and bityng of Serpents, and also is good to be
dropped into the ear to cleanse them, and h^lpe hearing Read Gesnerus. Lib.
iij. de Auibus.


Marcellus. What say you of Iuery.


Hilarious. IT is good, to astringe or bynd, and to race it with Turmerike and
Saffro^ putting in Diacurcuma in Tabulis, sodden in the water of Endive, Iuery.
wherewith many people are helped of a perilous hot and dry sickness called
R^gius morbus, or the yellow Iaundice. A drink for the Iaundice.



Marcellus. What is the virtue of Chickens and Hens?


Hilarious ALL fowls, which have hard pens, be strong of nature, Of house
Cocks. Capons and Chickens. Their flesh mutch commended.
as Chickens or Hens, says Auenzoer, which be most commended, and laudable
of any other flesh, and nourishe good blood and are light of digestion, and do
also comfort the appetite. Cock chickens be better than Hens. the Capon is
better than the Cock, they do augment good blood and seed, as Rasis
reports, and experience proves in men. both whole and sick. An old Cock
which is well beaten after his feathers be pulled of, until he be all bloody,
and then cut of his head, and draw him, and sees him in a close pot with fair
water, and white wine, Fenell roots, Burrage roots, Uiolettes: Planten.
Suckerie, and Buglosse leaves, Dates, Prunes, great Reisons, Maces, and Sugar,
and put into the Marie of a Calfe, and Saunders, makes a very good broth, for
them that be sick, weak, A good broth for a body which has been long sick.
or consumed: the brains of Hens, Capons, or Chickens, be wholesome to eat,
to comfort the brayn and memory: and will cause young Childrens Teeth to grow
quickly. And thus to conclude, these foresaid fowls be better for Idell folks
that labor not, than for the^ that use exercise, or travel, to whom gross
meats are more profitable. The Cock is the best clock, to keep the time.
Gesnerus lib. iij. de Auibus.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Geese?


Hilarious. THe flesh of wyld Geese and tame, Of Geese and Goslinges.
are very gross and hard of digestion, as Auicen says: the flesh of great
fowls, as of Geese, be slow and hard of digestion, for their humidite, does
breed Fevers quickly: but their Goselinges, or young ones, being fat, are
good, and mutch commended in meats, Galen says, of the Flesh of Beasts, and
Birds. Goose flesh breeds Melanchory.
But undoubtedly, Geese, Mallardes, Pecockes. Swans, and every foul having a
long neck, be all hard of digestion, and of no good complexions: but if these
be well roasted, and stuffed, with Salt, Sage, Peper, and Onyons. they will not
hurt the eaters of them. The Barnakle of Scotland, never lay Eggs, but are
bred only of the Ocean Sea, dead Gesnerus de Auibus. lib. 3.
There be great Geese in Scotland which bread upon a place called the Basse,
there be also Barnacles, which have a strange generation, as Gesnerus says,
which never lay Eggs as the people of the North parts of Scotland knows, and
least it should seem incredible to many, I will give none occasion to any,
either to mock, or to marvel: and thus I give warning to them which love their
health, to have these foresaid fowls somewhat poudered, or stopped with Salt,
all the night before they be roasted.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Cranes flesh?


Hilarious. Cranes, are hot, and increase seed.
SImeon Sethi says, their flesh is hot and dry, the younger be good but the
old increase Melancholy, they do engender seed of Generation, and being
tenderly roasted, does help to clear the voice, and cleanse the pipe of the
Lunges. Cranes be birds of a wonderful providence, Gesnerus de Auibus.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Duckes flesh?


Hilarious. THey be the hoatest of all domestical or yard fowls, and unclean
of feeding: Duckes are very hot of nature and Melancholy*
notwithstanding though they be hard of digestion. and marvelous hoate, yet
they will nourish the body, and makes it fat. Hippocrates says, that they that
be fed in puddels, and foul places, be hurtful, but they that be fed in
Houses, Pens, or Coopes, are nutriue, but very gross, as Isaacke affyrmeth.
There are sundry kinds of Duckes. Gesnerus de Auibus.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Pigeons, Turtles, or Doves?


Hilarious THe flesh of Turtles is merueilous good, and equal to the best
birds: and Auicen says, Doves are very hot.
they be best when they be young, and wholesome for flegmatike people* Simeon
Sethi affirms, that the house Dove is hoater than the Field Dove, and does
engender gross blood, the common eating of them is evil for cholerike
persons with red faces, Of Doves.
for fear of Leprosy* therefore cut of the feet, wings, and head of your
Pigeons or Doves, for their blood is that, which is so venomous through heat:
they be best in the Spryng time, and Harvest, and Isaac says, because they
are so lightly converted into choler, they did command in the old time, that
they should be eaten with sharp Uineger, Doves flesh. must be eaten with
Uineger.
Purssen, Cucumbers* or Citro^s. Roosted Pigeons be best, the blood that
comes out of the right wynge, dropped into ones eye, will sone help the eye,
if it swell, or prycke: and thus mutch have I spoken of Pigeons, or Doves.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Pecockes?


Hilarious. Peacocks flesh is hot and moist in the first degree Gesnerus lib. 3
THE Peacocke, his voice fears Serpents: Aristotle de natura any. and is hot
and moist, in the first degree. But Simeon Sethi says, it is a raw flesh, and
hard of digestion, unless it be very fat, but if it be fat, it helps the
Pleurisy* Haliabas says, that both Swannes, Craines, Pecockes, and any great
fowls, must after they be killed, be hanged up by the necks, two or three
days, de Auibus.
with a stone waying at their feet, as the weather will serve* and then dressed
and eaten, provided that good wine be drunken after them. Their Eggs are
noisome to be eaten, Dioscorides.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Swannes flesh?


Hilarious Every gross foul is Chollerike, and hard of digestion. Swannes
flesh, cholerike
The Swanne is gross, therefore flow of digestion. But the Signets be better
than the old Swannes, if there gal^ntines be well made, it helps to digest
their flesh The Swan is numbered among the unclean byrds, Leuiticus. xi. and
will sing a little before his death. Pliny Gesnerus de Auibus.


Marcellus. Swans sing.
What is the virtue of Her^nes, Bittures. and Shouelers.


Hilarious. THese fowls be Fishers, and be very raw and Flegmatike, Bitters*
Herons. Shouelers.
like unto the meat whereof they are fed, the young are best, and ought to be
eaten with Peper, Cinnamon, Sugar. and Ginger, and it is good to drink Wine
after them, for good digestion: Such meat, such co^plexio^,
and thus do for all Water fowls,


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Partriches, Fesantes, Quayles, Larkes,
Sparrows, Plouers, and Black birds?


Hilarious. PArtriches will bynd the belly, and do nourish much, the Cocks be
better then the Hen Birds, Partriges
they do dry up fleume and corruption in the stomach. Fesantes be the best of
all Flesh, for their sweetness is equal unto the Capon or Partrich, Fesantes.
but they are somewhat dryer, and Rasis says, Fesants flesh is good for them
that have the Fever Ethicke, for it is not only a meat, but a medecin,
Quails.
and does cleanse corrupt humors in the stomach. Quayles although they be
eaten of many, yet they are not to be commended, for they do engender Agues,
and be evil for the falling sickness For as Conciliator says, of al fowls
that be used for meats, a Quayle is the worst, Dioscorides says, Larkes
roosted be wholesome to be eaten of them that be troubled with the Collike.
Black birds taken in the time of Frost be wholesome and good of digestion, The
dunge of Black birds tempered with Uineger, Larkes hel^ the Collicke. Black
birds Plouers Sparowes, Woodcockes* small Birds.
and applied to the place of any that has the black Morphew, or black
Leprosy, oftentimes anointed with a Sponge does help them. The flesh of
Plouers does engender Melancholye. Sparrowes be hoate and provoke Uenus, or
lust. Pliny does descrybe their propertyes: the Brains be the best part of
them. Woodcockes be of good digestion, and temperate to feed upon. Al small
birds of the Fyeld, as Robin Redbrest, Linnets, Finches, Read Sparrowes,
Goldwinges, and such like: if they be fat, they be maruailous good, and do
greatly comfort nature, either roosted, or boiled: and thus I do conclude with
thee of birds: that the small fyeld birds are most wholesome for sick folks:
Read Gesnerus lib. j* de Auibus.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Fishes.


Hilarious. IN many Islands of this World, placed near unto the Ocean seas, the
people live there most chyefly by Fysh, and be right strong and sound people
of complexion, for as Aristotle says, consuetudo est tanquam altera natura,
custom is like unto another nature: but because I speak of Fish, I will divide
them in three parts. Three things considered in fish.

Sea fish wholesome then yt of the fresh water.


First of the Fishes of the Sea. Secondly the Fish of the fresh runnyng Rivers.
Thirdly of the Fishes in Pooles, and standing waters* The Sea has many gross,
and fat Fyshes, which be noisome to the stomach, but the small kind of Fyshes,
that feed about R^cks, And clear stony places, be more dryer, and less of
moystnes than the fresh water Fish, and do engender less phlegm, and wynd, by
reason of their Salt feedyng, as Galen says: they be the best fyshes, that
feed in the pure Sea, and chyefest of all Fyshes, for the use of mankind, and
Haliabas says, new fysh lately taken, is cold and moist, and flegmatike, then
the best of all next the sea fysh, is that which swimmeth in fresh clear
Rivers or stony places, whereas the water is sweet, being fishes that bear
skales, these be marvelous good: but if they feed near unto places where
mutch fylth is daily cast out, Muddy Fish not wholesome.
there the fishes be very corrupt, and unwholesome, as the said Haliabas says.
Fyshe that feeds in Fennes, Marshes, Ditches and muddy puddels, be very
unwholesome, Fish that have skales. be good, but fish without skales are not
wholesome.
and do corrupt the blood, they be gross and slymie, corrupt and wyndie: but
those that be fed in fair pondes, whereunto running Water may ensue. and
whereas sweet water, herbs, roots, and Weeds, that grow about the banks,
do feed the fish, those fyshes be wholesome* Galen says, Fysh that is white
skaled and hard, as Perches, Breames, Cheuins, Ruffes, Carpes, Roches, Troutes
etc. be all good, but vnscaled Fyshes, as Eeles, Ten^hes, Lampres, and such
like be dangerous. unless they be well baked or roosted, and eaten with
Pepper and Ginger, and Uineger. And note this, that it is not wholesome
travailing, or laboryng, immediately after eating of Fish, for it does greatly
corrupt the stomach, and as Galen says the nourishments of Flesh are better,
than the nourishments of Fish: and thus mutch generally I have spoken of Fysh.
Of the natures of Fyshes, read Rondoletius* and Conradus Gesnerus de Piss*


Marcellus WHat, it seems by these words, that great Fishes, which be
deuourers in the Sea, as Seal, Porpose, and such like, be unwholesome, and
that the small Fishes, as Cods, Whitynges Plaice, Smelts, Buttes-Soole, Pike,
Breme, Roche, Carpe and such as feed in clean stonye Waters, thou say they
be very wholesome. Eeles Lampers, and other muddy Fishes, thou do not greatly
commend, There be also some kinds of Fish soft, and some hard, but which be
the best.


Hilarious IF Fysh be soft, the eldest Fysh is best: if Fish be hard, the
youngest Fish is best, Fish soft and hard.
for it is either soft or hard, of hard Fish take the smallest, of soft Fish
take the greatest: provided that your Fish be not very slimye, and thus says
Auicen in his book of Fyshes.


Marcellus. What is the virtue of Shelfishes.


Hilarious. CRauises, and Crabbes, be very good fyshes, the meat of them, does
help the Lunges, Shel fyshes.
but they be hurtful for the bladder, yet they will engender seed. If Crabbes
of the fresh water, be sodden in pure green Oil Olife: this Oil dropped into
the ear luke warm, does heal burning obstructions, and stoppinge matter, For
deaf^es,
that hinders ye hearing. As for Lympetes, Cockels, Scallopes, as Galen says,
they be hard of digestion. Muskels, and Oysters, would be well boiled, roasted,
or baked With Onions, wine, Butter, Sugar, Ginger, and Peper, or else they be
wyndy, and Flegmatike: Oysters
cholorike stomachs may well digest raw Oysters, but they have cast many one
away, yet raw Oysters will cleanse the raynes.


Marcellus. What say you of Milk, Butter, and Cheese?


Hilarious. Women's Milk is the most gentle nutriment for young children, which
milk is of the decoction of pure blood, Milk of women is the best of al
Milkes.
by natural heat and drawn forth by the Nibles from the breasts or Pappes,
this is the first food of mankind: for like as bread is a blessyng of God for
men, even so is Milk one of the great blessings, as appears in the promise
which god made to Israel. Without Milk, it is not possible to bring up man or
beast. The best milk is of women, and most temperate, for it preserves
against consumption. The second is Goats Milk, which does norysh, and is
hoatter than wome^s. Milk of Goats.
Sheep Milk, is not so much noryshyng, and not pleasant to the stomach.
Young Cows milk is thicker, and full of Butter: Note also that iiii. things
must be considered in milk, the whitenes of color, Milk of Kyne Milk four
things considered in it.
the sweetness of savor, the pleasantnes of taste, the substance, neither
thick nor thin: it is good Milk, when a drop will stand whole upon your
thum nail, without sheading. There be three essences of Milk, Cheese, Butter,
and Whay, the best milk is of the youngest and fattest Kyne, or Goats, that be
fed in ye cleanest, dryest, and sweetest Pastures. whereas plentye of sweet
flowers are growing, and purest Clay or Chalk water, with wholesome layer. The
best time of milk, is in April, May, and June. The new Milk is most wholesome
for them to drink, which has clean stomachs, to drink i^ with Sugar, as it
comes from the Cow three hours before al other meat or drink, and then it
will not coagulate nor crude in the stomach, but quench Choler. Moreover milk
is not only good to young children and helthful people: but if it be sower,
then beware the stone in the raynes, Milk hurtful to whom.
and bladder through the same: and to them which have Fevers or headache, Milk
does much harm, as Hippocrates says Lac dare caput dolentibus, malum: malum
vero febricitantibus and quibus hypochondria suspensa murmurant, and
siticulosis: malu^ autem in febribus acutis, quibus biliosae sunt deiectiones,
and quibus sanguinis multi deiectio facta est: conuenit autem tabidis, qui non
multum febricitant and in febribus longis and paruis si nullum ex supradictis
signis affuerit etc,

That is Milk says he, is very unwholesome to such as have pains in their
heddes, Hyppocrates of the hurt of Milk, and ye vtility thereof
or that be sick of any Fever, and also to them which have any noise or wind
in the upper part of their bellye called Hypochondria, and that have
choleric decoction in hot fever, or have lost much blood: notwithstanding
milk is good for such as have a consumption without a Fever, and may be given
to them. which have had Fevers long time, if none of the foresaid tokens do
appear etc. And to conclude of milk, seeing oftentimes it is very evil,
and will through the couldenesse, and wind offend the whole Bodies of men,
Milk is a good thing in a common wealth.
what harm does it than to Sicklye persons? how be it, we se Milk is a
goodlye stay in a common Wealth, and the feeders thereof are people of a good
temperament, or complexion, as in Wales, Suffolk, Essex, and in a place in the
Mountains in ye North called Alston More, Alston Moore in the North
whereas little* tillage is, but bringyng up of Chattel: in this country the
people be al chiefly nourished with milk, little other drink they use, milk
excepted. This country was sometime the land of a worthy knight, called sir
Thomas, the Baron of Hylton, to whom I dedicated my little Book entitled the
Government of health, Sir Thomas the Baron Hylton his land.
promisyng in the same Book to set f^rth an other book, whereof the copy
perished with my Books, in shipwreck: and when I came to London to have
reuined my dead book, one William Hilton gentleman, brother to the said sir
Thomas Hilton, accused me of no less crime, William* Hilton let William
Bulleine to fynish his book of healthful medecines
then of most cruel murder of his own brother, who dyed of a Fever (sent only
of God) among his own friends, fynishing his life in the christen faith. But
this William Hilton caused me to be arrained before that noble Prince, the
Dukes grace of Norffolke, for the same: to this end, to have had me dyed
shamefully: That with the covetous Ahab he might have through false witness, and
perjury, obtained by the counsel of Iezabell, a Uine yard, by the price of
blood. But it is written, Testis mendax peribit a false witness shall com to
naught, his wicked practice was wisely espied, his folly deryded, his bloody
purpose let, and fynallye I was with Justice delivered. Notwithstanding, yet
am I by the same William Hilto^ still molested and troubled as much as lies in
him, to shorten my days, by some means or accidente, who with neither lawful
pollicye, nor false testimony, cold hitherto accomplish his wicked intent* Now
therefore blame me not my dear friend Marcellus, though this man be remembered in
my book hear of health, and preserving of life, seeing I was sometime in his
book of a false indightment, conspyring my death This man has let me, in
so much that I cannot run to the mark, that I did set before mine eyes,
therefore I must make a shorter course, fynishing with fewer things, trusting
not unprofitable for the commonwealth: whose profit I do seek, and more
would have done, this his malicious factes excepted, whose malice does the
less molest me, being a Stranger to him, seeing he has vexed a Lady,
which was his own Brothers Wife, whose shame, loss, yea and Blood he has
sought: which Brothers Wife redeemed mutch of his Land from loss, A bloody
practice against ye lady Hilton.
in lendyng him a great Sum of Money. And when this man should thankfully
have repayed this lady her Money, then he gratifyed her, as he did me.

And so to conclude, you that are gentlemen, beware of shameful ingratitude,
whereas you have reaped comodity. For it is the most leprous sickness against
nature, to do evil for good, preferryng a little lucre before honesty. worldly
worship, shame, and finally, Gods wrath or vengeance, due for such wyckednes
against conscience, and nature. What a very gentelman is
For ingratitude does degenerat mankind, and transform him most monstruously,
into an evil vile nature, from gentleness, into Churlishnes. For like as
gentleness with virtues makes a very gentle man: although sometime obscurely
borne: so does ingratitude, blemish, and defyle them, which can bring nothing
else for themselves, but Pedegrees, lines, cotes. and standerdes, most
aunciently descended, yet themselves void of al goodness. Thus I leave to molest
thine ears with him, who has thus molested me, profitable to few, and noisome
to himself. A lover of few, a flatterer of many, a vessel of ignorance, full of
ingratitude, unnatural to his Children, if that he spoyleth in law, Cataplasme
for M. Hilton of Bidicke, of the Bishoprik of Duresme.
which should be their relief: and thus I commend him to this Cataplasma, to
his mortifyed conscience. Faythles and fruitles he is.

Butter of nature is hot and moist, and has virtue to mollify hard
apostimatio^s yt are above nature, as Galen says: fresh Butter does ripe,
cleanse, and warm ye inward parts in meats, ointments or drynks. Fresh butter is
good to anoint ye swelling of Hypochondrion or belly, and for ye Phlegmon and
Bubo. Further to cause young children their teeth to grow, through the anointing
of the place and it is good to make annoyntment for the Pleuritici, And to be
drunk in wine or Beer, for the stopping of the lungs, Butter, Honey, Butter
the virtue of it.
and bitter Almonds, be wholesome for to cleanse the breast, and being put in
suppositories, and Glysters, do mollify the belly. New Butter meanly salted,
is good with Bread, Flesh, and fysh. The old Butter changing with many colors,
is the worst, it is noisome to the stomach. Butter is good in the morninge,
but not wholesome at night: yet Butter preuayleth against poysone in wou^des, it
will purge, cleanse, and increase Flesh. When y^ Butter is first made, there is a
mylk coming from the same somewhat sharp, sower, and cold, very wholesome to be
drunk in the morning or evening, Butter Milk called Char^n Milk is good
against hot burning choler: it opens the liver, cle^seth the gaul,
provoke urine, causes, sleep and nourishes much if it be eaten with Sugar,
and new white bread.

Cheese which is a part of Milk of the grosser substance, Cheese fresh is
best.
through the coagulation or cruddes, being gathered and pressed together,
from ye moist whay, the same cheese is finished: and if it be made of clean
milk and the Cream therewith, then it is beneficial to the stomach,
specially, if it be fresh and good it norisheth the flesh much, Green cheese
helps wounds.
and is good for green wounds to knit them, and will also quench heat, or
cleanse a spot in the eye, being laid thereon.xxiiii. hours. Cheese meanly
salted nourishes but little, by ye reason of the Salt. old Cheese stops the
flixe of the Belly, but it is hard to digest hurting the stomach, gaul, and
raynes, Cheese old stops the flux, but bredeth the stone.
and will breed the stone in the bladder, and cause the increase of melancholy
with much coldenes and drynes Gal. lib. 4. alimentorum facult* commends the
Cheese of his own native country, because of the pureness of milk, and sweetness
of the Cheese, but in his x. lib. of Simples, he refuses Cheese for the
sowrenes. etc. when stone pottes be broken, what is better to glue them a gayn
or make them fast, Sundry kinds of Cheese
nothing like the Syment made of Cheese. Know therefore that it will quickly
build a stone in a dry body, which is full of choler adust. And here in England
be diverse kinds of Cheeses, Much good Butter little good cheese
as Suff. Essex, Banbury. etc. according to their places and feeding of their
Cattle, time of the year, layre of their Kyne, clenlines of their dayryes,
quantity of their Butter, for the more Butter, the worse cheese. And thus I
conclude of Cheese. like as the Welchmen love it roasted, even so do Flemminges
love Butter at al times, and of all makings refusyng none, what color soever
it has, and from whence soever it comes, their stomachs are such.

Whay the virtue thereof.
Whay is the thinnest part of Milk. Whay with Fumitory sodden in May, and drunk
cold in the morning and Evening* has virtue to scowre, cleanse and open the
parts of the body that are stopped, provoke vryne, and makes clean the
Bladder, and is good to quench choler, helps the bellye, asswageth thirst,
yet it inflameth, and brings wynd to the guts but recocted or two times
sodden whaye, is the best whay and will bring sleep, and also is good in
Clisters, to cool, scower, and quench choler in the guts, or help the
^xcoriation in them, made by bloody Flixe: Galen commends Whaye lib. x.
simplicium medic. and Mesue does not a little praise the Whay of black Goats,
Gotes whay
and how it is hot and dry in the first degree unto the second: this whay is
good to be given to them which abound with much melancholye, or frensies, and
cleanses the water between the skin and the flesh, opens the Gaul, and
mollifieth the Spleen: in sharp acute Tertian Fevers, or stopping of the
vessels, with yellow choler, this whay does much help, to drink ye same, and
nothing is better to be dronk against hot Leprosy tha^ whay, it makes a clean
skin. Whay is used in many decoctio^s, and infusio^s, for lenitiues to purge
the belly* and thus I do end of Whaye, which is a good drink in Summer in
the common wealth, whereas good dayries be, as in Suffolk, the best country of
Milk, as about Lethringham, Stratbrooke, Laxefield Keishal* etc.

Eggs be commended of the most excellent Writers, as Dioscorides, and Galen,
Eggs of Birds.
that they do excel al other nourshing meats, and also are good in medecin
Isaac the Arabian, in his diates, does praise Hens Eggs, for that* they be
pleasant to the mouth, and profitable to the Stomach and that they nourish
more then other meats, and are soonest turned into good blood, and ef^soones
into seed of generation, specially Eggs that be new and white, but old Eggs
be most fylthy and noisome to the stomach. Furthermore Eggs have no part of
the Foul, says Galen Simplic medi. but a portion of the thing from whence
they come: Eggs three things in the^.
and Symeon Sethi says.iii. things must be considered of Eggs, the first is
the substance and cleannes of nature: the second is their age, either new or
old: the third is of the manner of their dressinge, as potching, see thing or
rostinge. Potched Eggs be wholesome to be supp^d up in the morning upon an
empty stomach. To cleanse the Lunges, breast and the rayns: hard Eggs do
bind: fried Eggs be hurtful to the stomach: next in goodness unto them are the
Eggs of Fesantes, and Partriges, and the Eggs of small Birds of the wood,
whose Eggs are white, but ye Eggs water fowls, as Swannes, Gees^, Duckes,
with all their kinds, be gross and not pleasant to nature, Eggs of great
^oules be not good,
although good to strong stomacked laborers. Doves Eggs, because of their
great heat, are more better for medecin then meat. Pecockes and Estrige eges,
be not good: of an evil nature and ennemy to mankind: In food, Of Eggs
their virtue.
the yellowe parts of Eggs be warm, and nourish the blood, and the white
of the Egg, is cold, and flegmatike. Galen does commend the white of Eggs,
because they freat not, but cool: and therefore they are good for medecines for
the eyes, and ulcers and wounds of the head, and other places whereas blood
does flow. Raw Eggs, with Oil of Roses beaten together, are good for Flegmon
in the Ears, breasts, Arms, Legs, or privy members. The white of an egg
the juice of Pomgranets: Uineger, and the oil of water Lillies, Eggs for
^^eepe.
are good beaten together, to annoint the forehead, to cause sleep. Eggs
sodden in strong sharp vinegar, until they be hard, eat them, and they will
stop the belly. Whytes of Eggs, the powder of the flowers of Pomgranetes,
Planten water, and Hypocistes, with oil of Roses, and Alume, For burninge
beaten in a leaden Mortar, will heal a burning or skalding in the flesh,
coueringe the place with a Launde Clothe, and annoynting the said Launde with
this ointment. Oil of Eggs is good to heal Serpigo the breaking or Crames of
the Lips, hands, skalding, burning, payns of the ears, stomach, Oil of
eggs
raynes, belly, and the privy members, which have great burninge, fylthe. or
heat: and finally, all the pains of the joints.

Of Eggs come all fowls, save Barnacles, which are ingendered of the
marvelous work of Occean Sea: Read Gesnerus, of the nature of Fowls. The
horrible Serpent called the Cockat^ise, is bred in the Egg: so is the
Crocodile, and many more Serpents, and many fyshes of the sea, Eggs of
serpents.
and little Worms, as the Antes. And thus I do end of eggs, whose yolks or
reddes be first bread, within the Fowls body^s, as it does appear when they be
killed, by the great plenty of the said yolks and no whytes, of which Yolks
the byrd is bredde. and nourished of the white: So is mankind engendered, and
formed of one part, and nourished of an other, Read Hippocrates in libro de
natura pueri


Marcellus. What virtue is in Coagulo Leporis.


Hilarious. THree half penny weight, after the old weight of the Apoticaryes,
tempered in wine, Coagulun or the cr^ddes of young beasts* that suck
and drunk does prevail against venim, or pricking of Serpents, bloody
flixes, and pains of the matrix, after the time that the ^termes menstruall be
past: it helps conception, but to drink it, it will dry the Seed, and let
conception. Aristotle does remember Coagulum lib. iij cap. 12. de historia
Anima* saying: it is the substance of Milk, of those beasts which chew the
cudde, and suck of a curdye substance, as Calfe, Lamb. Kidd, etc. And of
nature is sower and drying, and drunk with vinegar, it helps the falling
sickness as Galen afyrmeth lib. x. simplic. medic.


Marcellus. What say you of Sepum called Tallow, and Adeps, which is fat or the
grease of beasts and fowls. I pray you tell me?


Hilarious. FIrst of Tallow, understand that of nature it is warm, and therefore
it has virtue to resolve, Tallowe of male best are hotter the^ the female.
and make soft: and is used in sundry medecines, among the Chirurgians.
Notwithstanding, you must understand, that one Beast bears more warmer
tallow than an other: and the Male hotter the^ ye female As example, the Heart
hotter then the Hind: the Ram more warmer then the Ewe, etc.

But for the fattes of beasts and byrds, they be al warm and moist: some
more, and some less, according to their ages, fatnes, and natures, as example
following shortly said.

The fat or grease of ye Swannes, Geese, Duckes, Bustardes. Hens and Capons,
being fresh, does comfort the Matrixe, breasts, and joints, and are warm.
Gelded Swyn not salted is much like Oil, and moist and good against the
pleuresie, and used in many oyntmentes. Goats is harder than ye Swynes, and is
also dryer, and is good against the pains of ye great guts, in Clisters or
Suppositers Bears is warm, and melted with Laudanum, makes an ointment to
increase hair. Foxes, is good against cold and palseye, and pains of the
ears. Porpentine against baldnes, as the Bears grease is. Bulls and Calves
does warm, and are good to bynd and stop flixe, put in Clisters, ointments
etc. Male beasts, hotter and dryer than the female. Lions is most subtle and
hot of all fattes. Cattes hoate, and good, to annoynte Aches, and Goutes.
Seals or other Seafish, clarified with Honny will cleanse the iyen that are
dim Snayles cleanses the iyen helps the Cares, and is wholesome for bone
ache. Uipers good to annoint the dim sight, dropped into them, Young lusty
creatures, not salted and clean clarifyed, is best kept close. Raueninge
beasts hotter then them, which eat Grass: and the water Fowls, hoatter than
the land birds. Wolles called Oesypus, will resolve heat apostumations, and
Struma in the throat.



Marcellus. What say you of Mary, which in some place is called Marthe:
contained within the bones of Beasts.


Hilarious. IT has power to mollify, and make hard things soft, and of nature
is hot and moist, as Galen says. lib. xi. Simplicium medicamentorum. Example.

The Mary o^ Medulla of the Stagge or Heart is the best of al beasts, to mollify
Muskles, ligamentes, tendons, and the guts. Calves or young Steeres is next in
goodness, used in sondrye oyntmentes, and linimentes. Bulle and Goats are very
warm, and good in pessaryes for women. Ox, is good for the stomach, and the
Lunges, and increases, seed of Generation. Fox, for the palsy, and
tremblyng of the memberss. Back bone of beasts is dryer than other Mary, and
unpleasant to the stomach, drunk with Aligante, it stops the whytes in
women.


Al these must be kept in clean vessels, a loft in a chamber, with Windows
toward the North. For the South wynd, or standing in vessels nere to ye
ground, will soon corrupt Maryes, except they be clarifyed upon the fire, To
preserve fat.
and preserved in clean closse stone or Glass vessels.


Marcellus. What say you of the Gauls of beasts, or Fyshes?


Hilarious. THe Gaul is the most hottest and bytterest part of albeastes, the
place of Choler, and choler it self and dry, specially in hot Beasts, as
Lions, wolves. Foxes, Dogs etc, Gauls of Beasts.
more then of the other Beasts, which denyde the hooues. Even so it is among
fowls, the crooked bylled birds, are hottest of al next them which feed upon
weeds or seeds, and the water Fowls, more then the fyeld birds, as
Dioscori. affyrmeth- lib. iij. cap. lxxj. and are used in medecines as example.

The Gaul or fell of ye Scorpion of the Sea, the Sea Snaile, or such like of
the Sea for sore eyes. White Cock, and Capon, Hen, Fesant, Partrige, Dove,
against sore eyes, dropped into them. Crane, Osspray, for pains in the ears,
with oil of bitter Almondes dropped into them. Swanne, Mallard, will kill
worms. Bull, Ox, Cow, Goat, Ram, good for wounds or swellynges, and to kyl
worms in the belly made in Plaster. Swyne, For ulcers in the ears. Bears, to
annoint the heads and nosetrels, of them which have the falling sickness.


Also Gauls with Honny, and the juice of Rue, make a good oyntmente to annoint
the belly, to kyl worms, and help the Collike, and are used in inward
medecines. There are stones found within the Gauls of Oxen and Bulls, the
powder of them drunk, will cleanse the raynes and Bladder. As you may se,
Matthiolus in Coment. Dioscor.. lib. ij. cap. lxxj.


Marcellus. What say you of Brains


Hilarious. Brains are cold and moist of nature, of every beast or foul,
according to their kinds. Some not so moist as other, as you have had example,
of heat and cold beasts: and their brains are used in medecines. As example.

The brains of the Hare sodden or roasted are good to make young childrens
teeth to grow Hens, Capons, or Fesauntes, to be drunk in wine against
poison, says, Dioscorides,. Wesel or Ferret, dried, and dronk in vyneger,
against the falling sickness. Swallow mingled with honey, against the dinnes of
the eyes. Sheep prepared, good to cause teeth to grow, and mollifyeth
apostumations. Field birds costed are good to nourish the brain of man, when
it is weak. Calfe and Pigge, not good for Flegmatike people.



Marcellus. What say you of Livers?


Hilarious. THe liver is the Nutrimental part, and the fountayn of Blood, a
spongie matter, whereas the veins do begin, and is warm and moiste according
to the nature of the animal or Beast, and is used in medicine. As example.

The Liver of ye Mad Dog, roasted and eaten, helps him which is bitten
with a mad dog, Goats being clean, do comfort the sight, applied raw or
distilled, and is eaten to help the falling sickness. Wolf with Liver wort
dried, makes a goodly powder, to help the liver and lunges. Fox, clean
washed and dried does the same. Ass or Horse Broyled and Eaten against the
falling Sickness. Bore, both in meat and medecin, against the slinging and
biting of Serpents. More Hen or water Hen, against the stone, or grauel in
the raynes. Hen, Capons Chikens Partrige, Fesaunt, and al field birds does
nourishe and comfort nature.



Marcellus. What say you of the Horne^


Hilarious. NOt much, I assure you, although many things may be said thereof,
both for nature and property: I commend the discriptio^ to them, that covet to
be merry. Horns their nature.
And thus much will I say with Aristotle in lib. de natura Animalium, who says:
al beasts wanting their upper teeth, have naturally horns, for their defense:
as we do see the Bull, the Heart. etc. and they are good in medecines, as
example.

The horn of Unicorne is most excellent, to be drunk against venim and
poison, and helps the yelow Iaundice. Heart rased and dronk against Collike,
or Iliacke, Iau^dice, and the bloody flyxe. Goats makes good powder to cleanse
thee teethe, and stablish them, so does ye Hearts horn. Bulls in powder,
drunk with wine, helps to heal the Hemeroydes burnt in powder. The
Elephantes tooth will help the yelowe Iaundice, rased and drunk in Endive
Water. Sundry monsters of the Sea, are good against poison,



Marcellus. What say you to the Hooues of Beasts?


Hilarious. THey are their natural Shoes, keeping stil^ their old fashion*
Hooues of Beasts
which God has prepared for them. For neither horse nor Ox should be
profitable for mankind, but for the Houe: without which he cold not go or
travel, or have any shoe made fast. They are also good for mankind in,
medecin, as example.

The houes of ye Horses rased are drunk in wine, and good to help the falling
sycknes. Asses will do the same, and help the mother: burnte in perfume, sodden
in Oil, they will help Struma. Goats, with Uineger and Laudanum, will increase
hair^ annoynting the place. Any beast burned* the smoke thereof helps the
mother, and kylleth Gnats that trouble your chamber: Any Beast drunk in powder
makes women baren and fruitless. Mule, will retain most strong Poison, or
deadly venime. Them which are divided in two parts, are clean beasts. Leuit
Chap. xi.



Marcellus. What say you of Bones?


Hilarious. BOnes are the timber and strong posts which couple the body of every
living man, beast, fish, and foul together: without which we might not be
perfect. If any of the^ are broken, then are we lame. Thus bones be not only
good to nature when we are living: but ossa humana man's bones are good in
medecin. As example.

The bones of Man beaten into powder do greatly dry moist humors and sores.
etc. Lions strongly smitten together, will bring light fire and are most dry of
nature. Hogs beaten into powder, and dronk, are good against falling
sickness. Hens burnt with Egshels, made in Powder, make a frettyng powder.
Pigges are good for writing Tables, and to kyl worms in the stomach, drunk
in wormwood wine. Many sea fyshes are wholesome in medecin against poison.
Sepia or Cuttle, cold and dry will cleanse the skin* and Eyes.



Marcellus. What say you of vryne.


Hilarious. IT is the Whaye of the blood, conueyghed by the raynes into the
bladder: hoate and dry of nature, very salt according to the complexion of
the body that makes it as Manne and Beast. Fowls Pysse not, for the moyster
is turned into Feathers. Aristotle de nature Animalium. vryne is used in
Medecin. As example.

The urine of ye Man is weakest, except gelded swyne, and is wholesome to be
drunk against venime. Young boy, to be distilled with Litarge of Metal, a
water to wash against Leprosy, is made thereof. Mule, to wash hands and feet,
and against the gout and pains of the Joints. Goats or Cammels, to be drunk
against the dropsy, or swellyng of the belly. Boore, with oil of Wormwood, to
annoint the belly and kill worms. Dogs will kyl wartes, and ryngwormes.
Urchyne, will corrode and frette, cleanse, and skower corrupted humors.



Marcellus. What say you of blood?


Hilarious. THe life of every living thing consists in the vital blood*
without which, the soul can not remayn within the Body, and it is used often
times in medecin. As Example.

The blood of ye Geese, Duckes, and Kiddes is used in sundry Antidotaries.
Stock Doves, Turtle Doves, House Doves, and Partriges, is good for sore eyes,
and new wounds. Hare, for the stone, and bloody fly^e: Dear, for ye flix, or
terms immoderate running in women. Goats, which are fed with opening herbs
killed in June for the stone. Calfe fed so, for the same stone and also the
flix. Dragons is declared before. Swyne is cold blood: yet it is used in
puddings, but not commendable. Bears, and Bulls, are horrible, not good.
Sheep helps the Emeroides. He^nes, Cocks and Capons, stops blood, and
wounds. Duckes, keeps a goodly color long time: the Idolatoures did practice
therewith, dereyuynge the People at Hayles, with a Blood which they called holy.



Marcellus. What say you to the nature of ordure, the dung of Beasts?


Hilarious. ORdure or dunge, is the corruption or fylthy excrement, which nature
expulceth to the earth by the office of the guts. without which no creature
should live, if the dung were still retained, in the said guts. and yet it is
good in sundry salues, plasters, and medicines. As example. And they are hot
and dry of complexion, according to the nature of beasts,

The dung of Oxen and Kyne, does mittigate inflammation of wounds, and helps
stinging of Bees. Calves, sodde^ with vinegar, helps Struma in ye throat, or
swelling of ioints. Goats, does resolve and make soft: a plaster thereof applied
to the Matrix forces the child to the birth. Horse or Mule, sodde^ in wine,
strayned and drunk helps ye Iaundice. Sheep sodden in vinegar and oil of
Roses, resolves, quenches and heals burning and skalding. Dogs fed with
bones, helps the bloody flixe, drunk in milk: with Honey, it helps Angina,
to anoint ye place of the throat withal. Mise does cleanse, and with Honey
tempered together does increase hair in oyntmentes for the head. Swyne,
cleanses, it stops blood in flowing wounds. Curlues drunk in wine, helps
ye falling sickness. Corocodisus of Nilus cleanses the skin, the best of this is
white. Man is best in medecin, although most abominable to the sense of
smellyng: yet there is art to make oil for the Gout, swelling of the throat,
and to help Flegmon, of this ordoure of Mankind, and a water to be dronk
against the Falling sickness, Stone, and the Water between the Flesh and
Skin. And finally to help evil complexion. Read. Gal. lib. x. Simplicium
medicamentorum, and Dioscorides. lib.ij. cap lxxiiij



Marcellus. What say you of the Scorpion* Frogge, Mouse, Lasarde, Cantharides,
Horseleeche and earth worms?


Hilarious THe Scorpion is a cruel woorme, whose sting will prick to death,
Scorpion.
except the oil of Scorpions be gotten, which reconcileth the hurt, anointing
the place therewith. Also this oil is good to anoynte the raynes, to break the
stone, Frogge
and provoke vryne.

The Frog sodden with Salt, and clean Oil, and so eaten, helps against all
venime of serpents Dioscorides. lib. ij. cap xxv

Mouse.
The Mouse being roasted, is good to be given to children, that piss their
bed, to help the^. Further it will dry up the Foam and spattle in their
mouths. There are sundry kinds of Mise Aristotle's. lib. vi de Historia
animalium.

Lacert.
Lacerta with legs, a long tail, an earth Serpente. The head broken and
applied to any place on the body, whereas either prick or nail is fixed,
forth with it shall be drawn forth. This worm is much used of Chirurgens.

Cantharides are flies hot dry, and burninge, of nature, and have power to
blister and make issue, Cantharid.
and draw forth water: there be that write in their books of Physic, how
these flies may be drunk inwardly against the Dropsy and the stone, but I
dare not here commend the same, for fear of no small peril that might follow.

Horsleech.
Horseleeches are wholesome to draw forth foul blood, if they be put into a
hollow Reed, and one of their ends cut of, whereby the blood may run forth.

Snayle.
Snayles broken from the shelles and sodden in white wine with Oil and Sug^r
are very wholesome, because they be hot and moist for the straightnes of the
Lungs and cold cough. Snails stamped with Comphory* and leven, will draw forth
prycks in the flesh.

Earthwormes
Earthwormes are hot of nature and of the^ is a precious ointment made to close
wounds, and if they be sodden in Goose grease and strayned it is a good
ointment for to drop into a dull hearing ear, perouring it into the contrary
s^de. Earth woormes stamped, are good for payned teeth. The Oil of woormes is
greatly commended for the comforting of the sinews, ioints, veins and gout,
Oil of wormes^
they must be washed in white wine, and the Oils of Verbascum or Cowslops, of
roses, of Lyllies, of Dil. of Camomil, al sodden to geather, when it is cold,
put in your earth worms* stop your glass, let it stand xl. days in the
Sun, then strayn it, and it will make an excellen^e oil against ache,
Sciatica, gout. etc,

Read more of them Plini. lib xxx. cap ix. And thus I do end of Earthwoormes,
Earth the mother of every living creaure.
which are the bowels of the ground or earth, which earth is cold, and dry of
nature, yet the mother of each living wyghte, fostereth and gives food to
every creature, both sensible and insensible, and remains still, firm and
stable, and each creature has his original spryng, and first life upon the
earth: when they have run the race, some in pleasure and other some in
wretchedness, the earth does devour them again at length and swallow them, as
though they had never ben: Generation falls into corruption
and thus is generation turned into corruption, as Aristotle affyrmeth. But how
mighty is that Lord God, which with his blessed word did for our sakes make
the Earth to be our own free dwelling place during this our Mortal Life, to
what end, to abuse the same, as the old World did, for whose sakes he did
destroy all flesh, his small chosen people excepted? No forsooth, but to use
the Earth with diligent travel, in tillage, sowyng, cherishyng herbs, plants,
grass. etc. which be Gods gifts, both for our medicines and meat: not to
despise the sweet Creatures of God, Math, 6.
which spring in sundry times of the year, as flowers, fruicts, seeds,
barks, roots, with conning to be preserved for man's use, against the daily
danger of cruel sickness, which assalteth each man, Woman, and Child, through
the corruption of humors, and other evil accydentes of our Life. And for as
mutch as we can not make one flower, The prouydence of God.
neither can give to any of them his proper beautyfull shape, virtue, or
savor, which Solomon, when he was florishyng in his regal estate, was not
comperable to any of these flowers for their excellent beauty: Psalm. 103. Psalm.
104. Job. 26. Ier. 5. Genesis 3.
Therefore let us daily behold the Earth whereunto we must once come, and also
in the mean time, humbly laud and praise the high divine providence of the
almighty our Lord and God, who has laid the foundations of the Earth, that it
should not move at any time, and has covered it with the deep, like as with a
garment, the waters do stand between the Hills, yea he sends his Sprynges
to the ryuers, which run among the hills: all Beasts of the Field drink
thereof, and the wild Asses do quench their thyrst: besides them all the
fowls of the air have their habitacion, and singe among the branches, and
he watreth the Lillies from the Clouds. The earth is filled with the Fruicte
of his works: he brings forth Grass for the Cattle, and green herbs for
the service of Mankind, that he might bring food out of the earth, and Wine
that makes glad the heart of man, and Oil to make him a cheerful
countenance, and bread to strengthen his heart wythal. Wine Oil and* bread,
Gods gifts.

The trees of the lord are full of sap.


The Trees of ye Lord are also full of sap, even the trees of Libanus which he
has planted Therein the Birds do make their nestes: and the Fur trees are a
dwelling for the Storke. The high Hills are a refuge for the wild Goats, and
so are the stony Rocks a refuge for the Conyes. He appoynteth the Moon for
certain seasons, and the Sun does know his going down: he makes darkness,
that it may be Night, wherein all the beasts of the Forest do move. The Lions
roaring after their pray do seek their meat at God, the Sun aryseth, and
then they get them away together, and lurk them close in the dens. Then man
aryseth, and goes forth to his work, and labors until euenyng. O Lord how
manifold are thy works, in wisdom have thou made them all. The Earth is full
of thy Riches: so is the great and wide Sea also, Psalm. 92.
wherein are things innumerable both small and great Beasts: there sail the
Ships, and there are g^eate Whales, whom thou have made to play therein: all
these creatures weight upon thee, that thou may give them, meat in due time:
when thou gyuest them, Esa. 27. Io li. xi. Psalm. lxii.
they gather it, and when thou openest thy hand, they are filled with good
things: when thou hydest thy face, they are troubled, when thou take away
their breath, they dye, and they are turned again to their Dust. etc.

Every thing tourneth to dust.
Lo here my dear brother Marcellus I do end simply of Simples, praying thee
in the mean time to take them in good part: waying my present case,
disquietnes, and trouble. Good will ever was with me and shall be to my small
power, although leasour lacked, and time would not serve for the purpose:
Trouble has so hindered me, that I am constrained, presently to stay.
but when it shall please God that we shall talk together again, I will make
amends for all faults escaped, GOD willing, who ever keep thee, thine own,
Hilarious. Moreover, behold two old friends approach at hand, the one is called
Soarenes, and the other Chirurgerie. Let us hear what they will say, a little
while.

FINIS.
HEREAFTER ensues a little dialogue between two men, the one called Sorenes,
and the other Chirurgi, Concerning Apostumations, and wounds their causes, and
also their Cures, gathered by William Bulleine the Aucthour and Collectoure
of all these.

Dialogues, contained within this Book Uery profitable for every Reader, and
true obseruer of them.

And first begins the Sore Manne to speak, as Follows,

(:)

1579:



A LITTLE DIALOGVE Between Soarenes, and Chirurgi.
Soarenes. NOw our old Freindes have done all their long talk. very profitable
to each other, and also to as many as have heard them* I trust we shall spend
the time to the like effect, with no less profit, tha^ Marcellus and
Hilarious, which had comfort in seeking forth the sweet flowers of sundry
shapes in the fyeld, to their no small delight, all this last Summer. But now
the horie, stormy, dark Winter weather approaches nere, as Persius says:
Admouit iam bruma foco te Basse Sabino. Bassus, cold Winter does draw thee to
the fire, in the Mountain called Sabinus, says he. Cold weather says he,
draws nere, Flora is fledd, Boreas, perceth, and causes al beasts to
tremble, bereuinge them of their pleasant So^mer shroudes, under the sweet
leaves of green Trees. The Earth is new covered with white Snowes, hard
craking Ice, Sabius a famous Mountain in Italy Flora a Gods of Flowers a
harlot of Rome. Borias the Northeast wind
and horye frostes. Birds do quiver and quake, lurking in the holes of Rocks
and old Barnes, for their relief. The Beasts with slender empty bellies and
cold tremblyng Carcasses, do cluster in flocks, or shroud them selves under
the naked Bushes, with their faces from the fierce wyndes. These short Days,
and long nights, cause both man and beast to draw together in warm places,
and close houses, now the pore Bees, if they labored well in Summer, have their
close sweet delytes in warm Hyues in winter. Thus does Nature give providence
to sundry creatures, to foresee dangers to come, as honger, cold, storm.
Furthermore, God and Nature, have from the beginning, taught both man and
beast, not only to relieve themselves in health, but in the time of sickness,
and Soarnes: each of the^ are taught how to correct, stop, and purge such
humors, as do offend nature.

Thus man artificially, and beasts naturally, have a wonderful providence,
whereby the glory of our Lord, and God does appear of no small Majesty, and
deuyne power: which prepared his incensible creatures, as Man, Beast, Fysh,
Foul, Serpents. etc. And one of them to be both meat and medecin for an
other. His name be praised therefore. Amen.


Chirurgi. HOw beit good brother you have reverently spoken, of the Divine
providence. I perceive you did hear and mark well, what end our good friend
Hilarious made, Praising God with the holy Prophet David. Psalm ciii.


Soarenes. YE forsooth, although I be sore in body, yet I trust to begin with
good comfort, with a pleasant Comodye, and not end in a fearful Tragidye,
Tragedies begin ever evil and end the same.
For I have hard say in the writing of the holy Euangell, which reports from
the mouth of God, saying: before al things seek the kingdom of God, and then
shall all things be given unto you. If al things shall be given unto them,
which pray unto God, than shall comfort be given to the Careful, First seek
Gods kingdom.
Bread to the Hungrye, lyberty to the thrall. And fynallye health to the
Sick, and Soar. etc. As example, Christ gave health unto the Lepors, Lame,
Blind, etc. Even so I trust, being a soar Body, to be relieved at the mighty
hands of God, or through him, by his cunning ministers, among whom you are one,
which have done many happy Cures, as I have heard. Well, say further, we have
present occasyon, and time conueniente given unto both: you, to warn you
labor continually, and I again for health, patiently to suffer and learn
some wholesome doctrine, for my relief. For if the Builders of Houses, wherein
our Bodies be shrouded, be not to be sorborne: much less the repayrers of the
Bodies of men, wherein the Soul remains, can be spared when either Wound,
Soar, Botche, or such like assaulteth our mortal mantion of the body. To
conclude with you I will, followyng all this short Winters day, in the warm
house, to demand questions as well as I can, for my health and learning.


Chirurgi. Say on your mind a Gods blessyng.


Soarnes FOr that I never did Drink upon the sweet Fludde, or Well Spryng of
Philosophy, in my tender years: neither have sleapte under the noble
Mountain, and sweet two topped Hill, called Pernasus, Further, I did never
slumber, or forgotte my self, through Golden Sleapes upon Helycon that Noble
high Hill, and pleasant place, where sometime the nine Muses, gave forth
their Sacred gifts. But rather I have Drunk and Bybbed upon the cold
seuerus flood of the pale Water called Perenne: Ignorance.
and washed my self in the Dark Streams, of the forgetful Hellish Broke
Lethe in Clean forgetfulness. Therefore to say the truth of my self, my sore
Body and dol^ish Brain, can receive but small health, and Comfort, except it
shall please thee, gently to hear me: For curtesye is a goodly Schole
maistres, Curtas^e.
and Comfortable are sweet Cordials, and wholesome salues: and bitter* words,
are biting corosiues, to feeble Minds.


Chirurgi. YOu say the truth. Even so, soft Chirurgians make foul soars*
sweet words are pleasant to Women and young Children: Soft Chirurgians make
foul sores.
but plain true tales, ought to be among Men of knowledge, without curious
Cyrcumstau^ce, or Rhetorical colors.

Therefore go to your matter, the day is cold and short, the time passes
spedely away, and can never come again.


Soarenes. FOrsooth that is most certain: therefore let us spend the time well.
For my part I would know how to heal my soars which you do se here present
before and behind.






Chirurgi. I see them very well, and I trust by Gods grace t to teach you those

Soarn^^ WHat men of credit, both old, and new, have written of this most
worthy Art, of the hand craft of Chirurgi, or means thereunto, show me some
of their names, for to encourage me to love this said Art.


Chirurgi. I Shall call to mind, and note with Pen, a number of worthy men,
both old and new, Heathen and Christians, strangers, and Englishmen although a
great number whom I know not in this realm, which be worthy Persons, and
cunninge men, profitable to our common wealth. As the most worthy Fraternity
of the Chirurgians, of the most aunciente and famous City of London: whereas
through learned Lectours, and the Secret Anothomies, by, and through the
learned doctor, M. John Kaius, reueiling unto this Fraternity, the hidden
jewels, Doctor Turner.
and precious treasures of CL. Galenus showing himself to be the.2. Linacer,
whose steps he follows.

Who shall forget the most worthy Doctor William Turner? Doctor Kaiu^.
whose learned acts, I leave to the witty commendations, and immortal praise
of Conradus Gesnerus. Yet his Book of Herbs, will always grow green, and
never wither, as long as Dioscorides is had in Mind, among us mortal wightes.
The noble estate of knights, among the English or Brytish nation, which of
them did ever in ra^e, give a trippe, out run, or win ye victory of sir
Thomas Eliot knight? who has planted such fruitful trees that his graftes do
grow in each place in this our common wealth, and his Castle of health, cannot
decay. Sir Thomas Eliot knighte


Thomas Fair Doctor of Physic is not dead but is transformed and changed
into a new nature immortal: Thomas Fair Doctor
he has left a piece of dark earth behynd him, and gone over Lethes fludd^,
forgettinge this world, and with pleasure spends the time among the heavenly
Muses under the two topped Hill of Pernassus. Full well he knew Plini which taught
ye goodness of clean creatures, and also the pestiferous venom of deadly
Mela^choly Serpents, and their present remedy by the virtues of herbs of
so^dry kinds.

Doctor Androw Board, wrote also well of Physic, to profit the common wealth
withal. Doctor Androwe Board did see at Rome, no order, gnashing of teeth,
dw^llyng in wretchedness Thomas Panel.
This man declared how he was in a great city where he did see three hellish
Tragedies: the one was Nullus ordo, the second was Stridor Dentium, the third
was Horror inhabitans, and yet this Board was a bird of this nest or Cage,
called Rome, whereof he makes this report. I will not forget M. Thomas
Paguinellus, or Panel, who has played ye good servant, to the common wealth* in
translating good books of Physic.

Doctor William Kunyngham has well travailed, like a good soldier against the
ignoraun^ ennemy: setting forth the commendacion, praise* and profit of
Astronomy, Cosmography, and Geographye, etc.

How well was he* seen in tongues, learned in Arts and in Sciences, Natural
and moral. A father in Physic, Doctor william Kuningha^
