Blood does plentifully abound, which may be helped, by the opening of the
vein Mediana or Cephalica, or applying of boxing glasses, with skarifying the
place first if either purging do seem to long, or else the opening of the
vein, is not don accordingly. etc. Electuariu^ of Succorosarum. etc. be good
to purge blood.


Sickness. HOw then do you purge phlegm, which is one of the four Humors. I
pray you tell me? For lack of medicine, convenient for the same: there be
many which be daily cast away, as it appears by the rules of Physic.


Health, TO speak of phlegm simply, it must be purged with these Medicines,
as with Benedicta laxatiuae, Catarico imperiali: decoction of Polipodie,
Agarike. Purgers of phlegm.
etc. But salt phlegm is purged with the holy bitter medicine, which the
Greeks call Hiera picra simplex, Theodoricon, Anacarde, Hyperisticon. etc.
Sweet phlegm must be purged with Hyeralogodion of Memphis: and the strongest
Hiera picra, and such like things, for purging sweet phlegm, as appears in
the compoundes of medicines.


Sickness. How do you purge burnt red Choler, which is hot and dry?


Health. TO purge such choler, is with Trifera Saracenica, Electuario frigido,
Oxyphoenicum, with the decoction of Mirobalans, Cassiafistula, The Manna of
Calabria is the best of the world, and falls down in the night, as dew
upon flowers and leaves.
Tamarindes, Uyolets, and Manna of Calabria. Choler infected, must be purged with
Anacardium, or Agni corais, which grows upon a tree in India, which tree,
gives fire of it self, and brings forth fruit like unto La^bes hearts, but
very small, having a bloody juice: of this Rasis makes a good co^fection, for
simple taken it is venomous. There is also an excellent Antidotu^, in the.217.
Cap. of Nicolaus Mirepsus, in his book of Antidotaries called Theodoreton, or
Gods gift, wherein Anacardus in brought is. etc. Which medicine does help the
head, Theodoraton a divine gift.
lunges, stomach, liver, spleen, gout* etc. And also purges Choler, so do
with Hiera picra simplex, Rubarbe, Diaprunes. etc But when Mela^choly, that
cold, dry, wretched Saturnus humor creeps in, with a lean, pale, or
swartysh color, which reigns upon solitarye, careful musyng Men: which
humor at length, breeds and brings forth a terryble Child, called the
Fever quarten, Melancholy the worst humor of nature he b^getteth a son
called the Quarten. Compounded humor may not be purged with a simple medicine,
for they are to weak.
the same if he be not corrected, and banished away, will be his fathers
death. When he appears, correct him thus, as with the strongest
Hieralogodion, with the decoction of Seen, Epithymum, Hamech. etc. But in case
the humor be compounded, then you must also use compounded medicine: or
medicine simple, does rather hurt, than help in sutth cases. And why so? Mary
being simple, it purges but one humor, and suffers ye other corrupted
humors to remain: and what is ye cause thynk you? Truly none other, but yt it
is to weak, and lacks strength and force, which ye compounded medicines. As
example. George Tomson of Kelshall in Suffolk, has a Fever tercian (well)
your good will is to help him, A^ example between a simple and a co^pound
medycine.
and you give him a simple medicine: but what does your simple medicine profit
him? Nothing at all. For he which has a tercian, must be purged of choler, and
in such a case, because phlegm is mixed with choler, your simple may rather
put forth phlegm, which is moist, and not move choler, The fire will get the
victory, if the Water be not equal, or have the masterie. Good intentes and
good acts, ^e two things.
which is hot and dry, yea, the very cause and worker of the rygour in this
tercian, and so when nature has moisture drawn away from her, which should
quench the heat, then to conclude, choler shall be come the more hoatter,
vehementer, and cruel to nature, through a simple medicine, foolyshly given of
a good intent,

When blood does abound, or breaks forth at the nose, commonly on the right
nosthrell, or spetting of blood. etc. then diminishe it, as I have said by
dyscreete openyng the vein, with a fine Lanset, and no flem with a bearde,
like to a blood Iron, that Smithes do let horse blood wythal. For they will
sometime cut a vein through both the sides, and cause a crampe. etc. Ignorant
Barbers, their fruictes.
Also in diminishyng of blood, let not the Chirurgian without counsel, or
upon ancient experience, take or open the said vein or veins. As example,
William Downaby of Iken has a grievous pain in his head with ache, he can
take no rest. etc. there is no remedy, but to let him blood: the common Barbar
does take his Lanset, and opens a vein, as ye blind man shoots at a
Crow, he takes the first that comes to hand, or appears greatest, perhaps
a Synewe, which may chance to let out ye spirits of life, and kill him: well,
in case this Barber, for the pains of ye head, intend to open Basilica. which
is vena interna, or axillaris, growyng through the arm hoale, and brings
both from the heart and Liver, which are his roots, and through ignorance, do
open a great sinew hard by it, which is like a vein: in which sinewe the
spirits of life do swiftly run up and down, mixte with the blood of life. What
has he done now? Mary slain one. And what is their refuge in such a case?
The sign, say they, was in ye place, and he would be needs letten blood. But
in case if ye Barbers cunning be better, and if he open Basilica without hurt,
what does this help ye head? Nothing, or else very little at all. But if you
will help W. Downabies head, open Cephalica, called vena externa, with a long
cut, to let out gross blood, and foul matter, and cut not deep, for fear
of apostumacion: this vein I say helps his head, to purge first with,.j.ss.
of ye pills of Hiera simplex, a day before is better. Now if his pains be in
his breast, or rightside, ye or pleurisy, then open the vein called Mediana,
the middle vein, whose parents be Basilica, and Cephalica: this Mediana or
Cardiaca must be opened somewhat overthwart, and so shall he bleed well, to
help the griefs aforesaid: but when the matrix, raynes, Bladder, or Yard, be
troubled with grief, stopping, Obseruacio^s in blood letting.
or swelling, and mutch pains, then in a vessel of warm Water, open vena
talie the Ankle vein, called Saphena: for this old creeping vulcans, or lame
sickness, called Sciatica, with pains in the Huccle bones, can never be better
helped, than to purge with Hiera, to anoint with Oil of the same, as appears
in the Compounds, and to open the foresaid Sciatica vein, which is one of the
middle, and toward the outsyde of ye foot. And thus to open veins in order,
is the best way: and when time of blood letting, is not convenient, the^ apply
boxes with scarification, even as the place, humor, and time do require, and
this shall suffice of purging humors, with blood letting.


Sickness. I Trust to observe these your sayings very well, dear friends
Health. But how should I know, when medicines have taken their effect, and
wrought accordingly, to thend^ of their force, and virtue?


Health. THus you shall know, first, there is no man, but does take medicine,
To know, when medicine have wrought their effect.
to put away some grief: and when the grief is past and the body quiet, and
no pain in the stomach, then the medicine have wrought his good effect. Then
you may give the broth of a Capon, Chicken, or Hen, sometime Almond milk, or
clean stewed broth, drink small Wine, of color yellow and clean, and use
moderacion in eating and drinking, unless there follow an ephemerall Ague. Now
the next day after purging, the pacient may go to the stophe, or bathe: so that
he go thither, taking no cold, or do no labor, by the space of three days,
and then to use moderate exercise, and to feed upon meat, that will engender
good humors. And thus to conclude, the body, or any that are sick before
time, shall now be converted into a new nature, through the help of Nature,
and medicine?


Sickness. What else I pray you, is to be observed in medicine?


Health. THree things are to be noted, Time, Humor, and Region: where
purgacion is to be ministered. First, as touching Time, Time, humor, regio^
are chiefly to be considered.
there be two dyuersityes: The one is the time of the year, and the other is
the time of the Day, and Night, in which every Humor has his being. For
according to the variation, and alteracion of the time of ye year, the manner
of the purgacion must be altered and changed. And Hippocrates says, we must
purge the upper parts of the body in Summer, and the nether or lower parts
in Winter. (for why?) The humors do follow the property of time. Purge upward
in Su^mer, and downward in Winter.
In Su^mer purge with Uomits, in Winter by the stool, and not without a good
consideration of ye time, age, and kind of disease, and habit of ye body. For
they, which have straight throats, may not be purged with, or by Uomit, for
fear the spirit and breath of life be stopped and strangled, and so through
choking, ye body be killed. Again, purge not old men, by the reason of the
coldness of their complexion. In Su^mer purge above, early in the morning. In
Winter purge beneath, late at night. In the Equinoctial time, prepare at even,
and the next morning after your preparatyue, purge by Electuarie. etc. In
extreme hot Regions, no purgacions: in extreme cold Regions, none also.
Neither in the days, which be not temperate, as to hot with the Sun, or to
cold with Frost. etc. nor in the Cauiculer days, except great need require.


Sickness. How must the day, and the night be considered, in purgacions?


Health. WHereas the time of the day and night, be in length.xxiiij. hours,
which is called the artificial day, and artificial night, which.xxiiij.
hours, The day natural, and the day artfiiciall
make but one natural day, divided into four times six for the four
complexions. For every Complexion has his government, and dominion six
hours. First the blood begins at nine at night, and continues until three
in the morning. And choler from three after midnighte, until nine before
noone. And so the other two humors: first melancholy, and phlegm, have each
of them six hours, wherein they do raygne, and govern the body. The four
co^plexions reigning every one by hours
Now if it be Su^mer, and then you be minded to purge choler by vomit, then
you must give the said vomit, a little before ye hour of the day. So that when
it has remained, and stayed it self a while in the stomach, it may work in
ye hours of choler, to purge the same. In ye like appoyncted hours, so purge
melancholy downward, in his hour and make euacuation of it. If thou will purge
phlegm, let the pacient rest a Gods name, by the space of three or four
hours in the night, and then wake, and take his pocion, or medicine, a little
before Midnight, and not sleep after it, until it be purged. Now if you will
purge blood, in the morning open a Ueyne, The aged, the very young, weak
folk, and women with child, may not be let blood.
except very old, or yongue, or people consumed, or women with child, with
such I dare not have to do. If you will purge humors, otherwise than thus,
that is observing the hours, yea, and the mansions, or course of the Moon:
you shall greatly err, and do more hurt than good.

Furdermore, consider the diversity of humors, if blood abound, he must be
letten forth by ye vein, Cephalica, or Mediana, etc. If Choler be to mutch
above nature, Matter in the veins must be put forth by blood letting and
(...) the belly by Clister, and in the breast by vomit.
then purge by vomit: but if choler be mixed with blood, then let blood as I
have said, unless the matter be contained in the nether parts of the Belly,
then purge by Clister or pocion. etc. If phlegm or melancholy be beneath, purge
downwardes unless it be about ye mouth, or entrance of the stomach, or ye upper
parts of ye body: mark and wisely consider the time, in all these things, for
that is the chiefest poynct of all. For every thing, said the wyseman, has his
proper time under heaven. etc. And regions by which here in this place, the
humors be considered: also the places of purging, the upper part, the nether
part, the nostrelles, roof of the mouth, pores of sweatyng, and veins of
bleedyng, etc.


Sickness. What say you then of place, in whom the matter is contained?


Health. THE place in deed, as I have said, Place where medicine should be
ministered conveniently joined with time.
must be considered in which a medicine shall be given: whether it be hot in
Summer, or to cold in Winter. If the day be to hoate, you may cast Vinegar,
Sallow branches, Uiolets, Water Lillies: and be in a low Uaulte, or from the
Sun, and temper the place, where you will purge. On the other part if the
place be to cold, make a fy^r of Charcoales, or a stoue, which is a fire
secret felt, but not seen. Close Windows from wind, in a pretty warm Chber,
wya^th good whole hangyngs or seelyng. The pacyent to have light warm clothes,
and slyppers, clean, and well lyned: sweet linen* as sheets, shurtes, and
Kerchiffes, a close chair, lyned softly with a back, having a clean round
basin, or vessel within the same, to receive the stools or purged matter. And
then to have soft Cotton or cloth, to make clean natures privy place, you know
my meaning. Forget no sweet perfumes by art, for nature will play the stinkyng
Beast, I tell you truly. Also in this place no noise, nor utter Monkish
silence, but be myndfull of some honest merry matter, or pleasant tale, or
things that will rejoice the spirits. etc. Cold does take, and is not taken.
And this place must be thus used, in the time of purgacion: but still I say,
beware that you take not cold, or rather cold take not you. For in such a
case, i^ he get the victory, then he will put you into a sheet, and send you
to the God of Qui Lazarum.

thus he punysheth them, as Job says, in the Night, to reform them. And by

Men do dream, according to their temperament or complexio^.

etc. For look how mutch the soul is purer than the body* even so the joys,

end and beginning of immortal life.
yea from the King and Queen* which of all be honored, obeyed, or flattered

Yet because I am a man of the creation of God, scourged with many in fyrmityes

Health I Am sorry for thy double aff^iction both body and mind, thou have
told a lamentable tale: well, I will say thus much to thee, many hands make
light work. Bear these grefes quietlye, thou have many to help thee in this
world. For there is nothing under the sun, but vanity and affliction of
mind. Every living man has trouble, thus must needs be wisely suffered,
because it cannot be avoided: and wise men may not despair in aduersitye, for
comfort will come I warrante thee, be neither to effeminate or childish, when
trouble assaulteth thee, for then thou art clean gone. But arm thy self
wisely with magnanimity, forsee the end, hold up thy head, and synke not. Use
this world like a S^age, play thy part there on in thy vocation, for the time
honestly, serve God reverently despise not civil policy, Profit the common
wealth, keep good company, be not ungrateful to thy friend. Depart from thine
ennemy, and yet beware of thy friends, Speak gently, trust not them that
commonly use swearynge, slander, Eccle. v.
drunkenness, and be full of ielousy. Live of thine own, though it be but
poorly. Be not bond, if thou may stand at liberty. Go not to law with
Lawiers, for they will hinder thee. And beware of a flatterer, he will betray
thee. Be not variable in religion, observing time, and the manners of men: But
obaying God which does not change. There be three sundry men, A three stringed
whip.
which have done thee never good: The winker in his tale, the Laugher in his
rage, and the Fox colored, which will not stick for blood sheading, false
witness, or perjury* yet pray for them, and let go displeasure. Be angrye
and sin not. Let not the Son go down on thy wrath. Trust not to the
world, yet behold it, and thou shall se maruaylous things wrought therin^
Eccle. iiii.
Thou shall see much wrong done daily under the Son and behold the tears of
such as be oppressed, and there is no man to comfort them, or that will deliver
or defend them from the vyolence of the oppressors, but only God, therefore
follow the counsel of the wise man, for there is nothing better says he, for
a man, than to be joyful in his labor, for that is his portion. Eccle. iii.
And for as much as mankind, has labor, travel, heaviness, sorrow, and
disquietnes al his life, and yet shall leave al his labors to others, which
never saw them, is it not better then, for a man to eat and drink, and his
soul to be merye in his labor, and this is the gift of God says the wise
man. What thing is bent for mankind.
And thus to conclude if thou be troubled in mind, pray only to God, and ask
counsel of the wise: if thou be sick, seek the Physician. Honor him because
of necessity, God has created him. For of the highest comes medecin. and he
shall receive gifts of the king. The wisdom of the Physician, brings him to
great worship: in the syghte of the great men of this world he shall be
honorably taken. The Lord has created medecin of the earth, E^od. 15.1.
Regua^. 4.
and he that is wise, will not abhor it. Was not the bitter water wade sweet
with a Tree, that men might learn to know the virtue thereof? The Lord has
given men wisdom and understanding, that they might be honored in his
wondrous works: with such does he heal man, and takes away the pains, of
such do the Apothecaries make a confection, yet cannot a man perform al his
works. For of the lord comes prosperous wealth over all the earth. My son
despise not this in thy sickness, but pray unto the lord, and he shall make thee
whole, Leave of from syn, Eccle. 38.
and order thine hands aright. Cleanse thine heart from al wickedness: this is
the counsel of Jesus the son of Syrach, in his holy book. Good counsel in
the time of trouble.
Chap. xxxviii. And now shall I show unto thee, what time medecin shall be
given. Then do thus. Sometime medecin is given to sleapward, or before sleep:
and sometime before day, in the morning, to ye waking time. First in the time of
waking. then give Liquid, or moist medecines, and also easy: and specially
when we must purge light humors in the stomach, For as a moist liquid medecin
in Pocion is soon dissolved, even so she will spedely and quickly, do her duty,
and work her feate effectually in her place whereas she has power to convert
actiuely, and change things into her nature, Even so nature has power to
change meat and food unto her own proper virtue. Medecin does change and
meat is changed.
Therefore note this, that when such medecines be ministered: if the Pacient
should then sleep, at such time as the natural heat begins to increase,
then the said sleep lets the virtue and good operetion of the same
medecin: resolving the body into paynful sweat, and attractinge and drawinge
humors out of order, making the Paciente sicker.

Item in as much as Liquide and light humors, be soon dissolved, then it
follows, that the same humors do eftsoons come to the place of expulsion,
Therefore to conclude, if the said Pacient do sleep at that present, it might
then chance, that ye medecin would not convert, or change the humor, or
cast it* forth: but rather resolve humors, in the body, which would cause most
paynful peril, and noisome sickness and disease, Why purgations work not
naturally.
while as the putrifyed matter remains still in the body, not purged. But when
as the pacient has taken but a light supper, he may take pills, so that the
said pills be new, and the pacient not very fat, One may sleep after pills,
but yet beware of old dry pills.
for fat men and women have small guts, and pills may chance hurt them.
And when we purge hard matter, or humors in the extreme parts of the body,
we minister pills, But for as much as pills be hard of resolucion within
the body, one may sleep well upon them, before they be resolved. For sleep
brings inward warmnes: and warmnes* makes resolution, and furdereth the
workinge of Pills, which must take their effect in the extreme parts, as
head: hands, and the feet. And thus I say, pills may be given without hurt,
when the pacient goes to his natural rest and sleep. Provided, that in the
morning, when they begin to work, Pills may be made of al kinds of medecines.
then the said pacient must sleep no more at that time. And note that pills
may be confected, of al kinds of medecines, and there be pills given before
meat, for them which have evil digestion, called Pilule ante cibum.


Sickness. Sometime it* comes to pass, that in a manner unadvisedly, or
sodaynlye, the Physician does give a Purgation or Medecin, not considering the
complexion of his pacient, therein does he well or no I pray you?


Health. THE complexion would be known, but when there is no opportunity or
leisure to know the complexion, whether it be hot, cold, moist, or dry. In
this cause let us use a preventing medecin, or an Antidotarie, The observation
of complexions.
whereby we may both prepare ye way, and also know whether the matter be hard
or soft, to be removed with the same preuentyng medecin, either yea or no:
also in this case, let somthinge be ministered before, which may gently resolve
the humors, Benedicta laxatiua, stomachicum carthaticum, imperialae. Or else
let us give to the pacient some gentle pills, and decoction of Polipodie,
Agarice, and Hermodactiles, tempered white wine, putting thereunto purifyed and
clean honey, and then give it to the Pacient when it has stand* until it come
to a residence do the same with Polipodye, Esula, sodden in wine, putting in
a little Cinamome. For this does resolve and unbind phlegm, and Purges it
well, or else gather solutyue and losing Herbs: as Mercurye, Beats,
Mallows. etc. sees them in fat Porke, putting in a little Seen. And in
case this lose the said Sick Pacient, if he mark the quantitye of the
Euacuacion, or things purged, so he may be contented therewith.

If he feel more grief in the belly, or pain burninge, or noysomnesse: he
may then prepare a stronger, or one weaker, according to his humor, age or
time of the year, To give medecin in the fit of a Fever, is perilous.
or habit of the body. And in all medecines beware of this, that nothing be
taken in the fit, rigor, terror, or hour, when the pacient shall be vexed,
tossed, or tormented with quotidian, tertian, or quarteine. etc.

Health. IF he be on your side, who can be against you? Nothing in Heaven,

Roma. viij.
you are safe from all Storms. I do commend your Godly zeal, and

yea, and commanded the Apostles to carye Oil with them, to heal the Sick.
Why do you then talk thus, leauyng out this word mean? Which is like unto

By which mean, the holy Spirit of God is perceived, as example. The Apostle.i.

which is God the holy Ghost And although the gift of healynge, was

Infidelles have singular gifts of God.

because of the ungodly, neither be thou envious against the evil doers, for
they shall be cut down like grass* and be withered even as the green herb.
Put thou thy trust in the Lord, and be doing good, that thou may dwell in the

thy hearts desire. He which loves God, shall have hearts rest.
Commit thy way unto the Lord, and put thy trust in him and he shall bring it to

ministers for the soul. And whereas thou art sick, Ecclesiast.
and sore in body dispyce not his ordinary means, but honor ye Physician,

therefore will now cease, and give place unto the Divines, and Moral men, which
with tongue and pen can give good counsel, and heavenly Cordialles for the
sick, sore, afflicted spirit.

And now to the first part of your question conserninge Physic, which is the
race wherein we begun to run. Let us now come again into that plain
path, hold on still, and then we shall the sooner come to our ways end. And then
sit us down, and rest us quiet^y a Gods name: for rest is an Image of Heaven,
after labor. Your question was thus of them which do abhor the sight, or
smelling of medicin, being ready to vomit also, to behold the vessels,
wherein medecin was given: to that question you answered your self. The
cause was, the stomach does abhor those things that offend the senses, as
in seeing, smelling. etc. (But in deed our sense of smellyng is worse then any
other living beasts, as Aristotle says in his book of senses: Odoratum
peiorem habemus quam alia animalia. Further says he, Aristo. in libro de Sens.
man only does smell and take delight in the odours of flowers or sweet things:
Even so does his nature abhor stinking things But specially they which be
clean of Nature, or by accidents. And this is known by natural Philosophy,
and Physic: and whereas the Philosopher does leave there the Physician does
begin. Although there be many secret hidden desires within nature, known
only to the same, and hydden from ye Physician: Nature has many hidden
desires, unknown to the Physicians.
As example, some women being with child, desire Tar, yea, I have seen them
eat Soap, and hurt them not, with other vile things, that I will not name.
Without nature had led them, death would f^llow: yet Physic compteth them
deadly. These be the secret hidden things with in nature.) But now to the
question.

When nature is so weak and feeble, that it does lose and abhor, to see or
smell medecin: the best remedy is thus, that you give laxatiue Claret, made
after this manner.

Medecines for feeble stomachs to purge ge^tly
R. Clean Claret, or white li, x. of Polipodie, Honey, ana. li. ii. Agarik.ii
Cinnamon, Cloves, Spicknard, Ginger, Galingall, ana..i of Peper.iii. First make
it thus: temper the clarifyed Honey with wine and draw it through a Colander,
and stamp the Polipodie, and strongly strain it, and sees it to the third
part, and beat your spice into powder, and put them into abagge made of a piece
of a serce or bulter then put your tempered wine, Honey, and juice of Polipodie,
together, put in your bag with spice, and sees all in a closse vessel well
Tinned, and strain your bag oftentimes. And then receive this drink, and
give a draught to your weak, feeble, stomach, according to your strength. And
for Honey you may put in clean Sugar, and to your spices, you may put to
Seen..iii. And when you drink of this, you must drink clean cold water, or
runninge water after it. Now sir if you will restrain, or stop the body, when
it is to much laxatiue: or draws nature to vehemently. Then give hoate water
to drink, and this is both pleasant, and profitable to nature, although to
many it seem unpleasant. The^ take spices in pouders, according to the
property of the humor, or complex^on, which ought to be purged, puttyng the
water and the said spices with a little Sugar, into a closse vessel of glass
and sees it in a vessel of water. Provided, that the said vessel of Glass be
wrapped in Hay, or else stand in a plain stillitory, making a good fire under
the same, and then you may take it forth, after it be well and closse sodden,
and strayned. And either receive it your self, or else give it to others. But
if it be bitter, put in more sugar into the same, to please your stomach.
The more spice you do take* the more virtue it has for the melancholy, or
flegmatike.

Item you may do thus, take a mean quantitye of Elleborus albus, chopped
small with a cuttinge knife, sees it with Barley, with clean Water, into a
thickness. Then feed an Hen eight days, with the same Corn, and Elleborus,
and at eyghte Days end, kill the same Hen, and seethe it, and put in no
Salt but Croomes of Bread and Sugar, and drink this broth. Put in Manna if
you will, and eat the flesh of the same Hen, and it will purge the same,
without any molestation or hinderaunce to Nature, I assure you, and that I
have proved. Even so have a great number proved, Elleborus albus, the poyso^
thereof.
Ell borus albus, to their great hurt, and peril of death by vomittinnge,
yea, almost expyring among the Dog Leches, and murderers. But beware of them,
and then thou shall be called Health, and no more sickness, by Gods grace.


Sickness. IS there no consideration to be had, in the ages of Men, or Women?
may the medecin giver, give hand over head, to the tender Child, middle age,

Health. YEs surely, diversity of age must be considered, in the ministracion
of medecines laxatiue. For purging or relaxing medecines be given to sundry
sorts of ages: as to boys, Men, women and children must take medicines
according to their strength and age,
springaldes, Lusty young men, and to the aged. Even so to Womenkynde in their
degree of ages, every one of these has his or their proper purgation. As
Manna of Calabria to young things, and the same to old folks: or else some
gentle solutiue medecin, and to women with child, no laxatiue medecin, until
the v. month be past: and then put gentle ones, as Cassia, Manna, or the
syrup of Roses solutyue, Even so she may have some Seen of Alexandria, their
leaves sodden closse in broth of a Chicken, or Mutton within a covered, earthen
or Tinned pot. Also suppositours may be given to these foresaid folks, that
be excepted in purgacions. And furthermore, with discrecion, the aged may
receive a gentle Glister: because the said aged be grieved with corruption of
the raynes, bladder, and guts. For if children be purged much, because the
humor is light: they shall be in danger of their lives. And living, the said
purgations will make wretched. alter the complexion, and expulse the natural
moisture, whereupon they should increase and grow. As we see young children
having laxes, be wretched, leave, swelled bellyes, crampe, and conuultion. etc.
The aged also in such, shall lose moisture of blood, and fall into melancholy,
drynes, feebleness, lack of sleep, and consumption, through resoluyng of a
strong laxinge medecin. But yet to them which be not in extremes, either of
age or sickness: there be many gentle resolutions, or clensynges of humors, and
may be given without danger. As Reubarbe infused in Cichory water, or the
water of milk, and Mirobalans. But by the way of Parenthesis, let every
minister of medecin fear to give any thing that does, or will dry the body, or
bodies to much, of young or old men: yea, or in the middle age, specially of
choleric men. As example, I did know one, being then a young practicioner,
seven years past who did minister a Purgation wherein was Scammonye, unto a
right worshipful, and a famous Knight, Beware of drying medecines in Summer
for choleric persons.
called sir Robert Wingfeeld of Lethingham, which ^ft soones gave him twenty
stools. The cause was as I suppose now, this Scammony was not prepared

ignorant murderer.

Now again to our matter, neither purge young children nor old men in the heat
of Summer, A cauiat for Summer.
and if you will needs do so, then you shall be commenced Doctor of Physic,
wearing William Summers hud for your labor, which will bring you to no small
estimation. So trimly to set the cart before the horse, and to play blind

the heat of Summer, resolution of humors, is quickly made with purgation after
which, ensues euacuacion to much abundantly, to the utter hurt of nature.
Young* lus^y, or sickly persons, may be purged at any time: so the said purging
do agree to the time, and the complexions And they may take more of the
purgations, than the children or old people may, because of their strength. But
yet the spring time is best, and ye Dogs days worst to purgacion: but

a Thief that will steal away the most precious thing called life, which is
our best jewel through the venim of death. But yet death finisheth and makes
an end of every matter, and of every person good and badde. Before whose

For happiness is not common to every living creature: but life and death be
common to every living thing. As Aristotle says in the book of life and death
Vita and mors sunt communia omnibus animalibus, And life is but dwelling of the
soul and body together for a time. And in the mean season, clouted and
patched up, with meat, drink, cloth, sleep. And when life is in peril, then
help Physic, Physic, I pray you help: we be afraid to die godly because

rather, there be many do so live, that they fear no punishmente or Hell,
after this life, do they never so wickedlye. Excluding God clean out of their
hearts, or rather God refusing them for their wickedness, There is a Psalm
wherein David lamenteth, the wretched estate of fools, saying Dixit insipiens

Would God that there were few of them. Oh Sickness, Sickness, although thou sekest
Health, and parhappes may obtain it: yet thou shall once change this life,
and see an other World, and also God, for no man can see him perfectly before
death, nor be saved, which in this life, believes not in him.

the small birds of ye Hawk. And if they escape wounds curable, there be

Health ALL is in vain, dear friend, if we do forget the temperament, or
complexions of men, or women. You therefore do very well in calling them to
remembrance: for one complexion, can not bare so much as an other in purging.
No more then a little weak boy, or young Ladde can bear as heavy a burden,
as a great lubber which is sturdy and strong to labor. We therefore give more
a purging medecin, to the flegmatike body than to the choleric, and yet more
to the melancholy, then to the flegmatike. Why so? Because melancholy is an
harder humor, then the phlegm is: and humidity, or moisture, more abounds in
the phlegm, then in the melancholy, Purge phlegm mo^e than chol^r* and
melancholy more the^ ^^^gme.
As example. Therefore when you will give Scammonye, to any choleric person,
give him a penny weight, to the flegmatike, two P^nye weight: but to the
melancholy, give three penny weight, For a cholerik man must have but little
given him. The cause is, the said choler is hoate and dry: and if he should
take as much Scammony, as the melancholy, it would inflame him, and rather
consume the pure natural humiditye, then purge the noisome fylthy humor,
which is the cause of the sickness. For the slender man, Choleris sone^drye*
ther^ore purge but little (...) the fleshy body has much moisture, the^fore
purge more. Of the quantity o^ matter to be purged.
may bide worst a quick purgation: as on the other part, the more fleshy, I
mean flesh, and not gross fatnes, the more he may abide a good strong
euacuacion, or strong medecin, by the reason they have the more moisture and
humidity than the said choleric have.

Furthermore, as concerning matter to be purged, sometime it is much and at
other times, it is scarce, or of little quantity. Therefore the medecin. must
be given accordingly sometime much, and sometime little, small matter is
dispatched with small medecin, Except it be wrapped, compacted, and thrust
together: and then a preparatiue must be given, and after purged. But whereas
much matter is, there it does require a greter medecin, notwtstanding, Much
humor must be purged by little and little, and not at once.
it ought not to be euacuated al at once, but by little and little, and by times
if so be it be in the extreme parts of the Body, as the head, hands and
feet, be the extreme parts.

And in this case. we have ye noble famous prince of phisicions, for a witness
how this matter should be handled, in the best manner saying: Nam secundum
multum est repent euacuare, sieve replere, fallax est, and omni^o inimicum
naturae. That is to say, to make a large or a quick euacuation. or purging:
Replexion, or fylling, is a disceitful thing and an utter ennemy to nature.
Therefore beware of extremity in all things, and use the mean and best way, a
gods name, what else have you to say?


Sickness. I Have almost forgotten, how to receive Moiste, or hard Medecines: it

Good sir should they be given hot, or cold What say you to the matter?


Health. TO the healthful, liquide or moist medecines, be given cold: and to
the sick persons, Cold medecines to the whole, but warm to the weak must be
given.
they should be given warm, because the virtue of the medecin shall in them
lose, deuyde and expulse matter, when the said medecin stands in the
stomach or guts: which in the whole bodies, the pocion or medecin will take
his effect in good part, and this must be done at Morning. The hard medecin,
as I have said at Evening moist, as pills: l^zi^gs after midnight. Pouders at
none in broth, clari^ied posse^ ale at eueninge. And why be pills given at
Night? Because a man may Sleep well after them. What does Sleep then
prevail? Because sleep makes the Body warm within, and Pills be very
hard: and therefore they must be resolved with warmness. To what manner of
men. To them, which have the rich men's sickness. What is that? Forsothe the
gout, which many gentlemen be tormented wythall: as example. Sir Rychard
Fulmerston knight, Barthram Anderson Esquyre. etc. The Gout loue^h rich men,
but is afraid of poor (...).
For the Gout is sore afraid to dwell among poor men: for they keep him so
hardly, and punysh him with cold, and labor. etc. But the bitterest pills of
all in ward medicines, do fardest pearce to the hands and feet, to purge and
heal them. And in the feet the Gout is placed: therefore pills be good for
the Feet. Who can denay it, which I have spoken?


Sickness. AFter purgations, oftentimes it happens, that the Pacient falls
into a Fever, called Ephemera febris, or a light Ague: which may do more hurt
to nature, if it be not helped quickly. What is the cause I pray you tell me?


Health. TRuly, there do oftentimes chance, such evil accidents after
purgations, through sundry causes. Of overmuch purging the body, the reamedy to
help the same.
As sometime by to mutch euacuacion, clensing, or purging. Whereupon the
Spirits cause unnatural heat, and thereof insueth an unnatural flaming or
heat called an Ephemeral, and likewise it chances by ouermutch eatinge or
drinking, as of Wine. etc. and also by cold or by attraction of over many
humors to the stomach, or the lack of the quantity of medicine, which has
no virtue or strength to be purged, but remains still in the stomach, and
thereby does continue putrifed, hurting the body and making a fever: if this do
chance, then put the Pacient into a Bath, if he be able. And let there be
made a good fire, or hot house, for this Pacient, and anoint him before and
behind with Vnguentum dialthea, or else with Vnguentum Martiaton and bring him
close with clothes, from the balne or Bathe to his Bed, and keep him from
sleep eight hours: and so shall he be dispatched clean, and made whole,
being purged again* to cleanse the inward parts, as the stomach. etc. But if
ye Pacient be to weak to come to the Bathe: refresh him in his Bed, with
wholesome suppings. Keep him warm, in a sweet chamber, and then give him an
easy laxatiue, of drawn Cassiafistula..j. with water of Borage..iij. or else
with sweet Calabria Manna..ss. And often it chances, that Men are dry after
purging, then give them small Ale clean brued, or P^isane, or else clean cold
water, Gum Arabicke, and Dragantum be sodden. And to gargarisme these
things in his mouth and Throat: and to put Prune stones in cold water, and
chafe them with the Tongue up and down in his Mouth, and so renew them
still. And keep the mouth, Teeth, and tongue clean with washing, clensing, To
cool the mouth.
and scraping: and this shall comfort the sick Man. Which else shall be
corrupted, defiled, and so anoyed, that it shall be as paynfull to himself, as
hugely, and noisome to the beholders of the said sick Man or Pacient.


Sickness. WEll, then I do perceive, that this should suffice to help them,
which be not well purged before: and also to cool them, in their great
thyrst and dryness.


Health. NO not so: it is not sufficient to quench. For, first you must
understand, the occasion of this thyrst: first that it cu^meth of hot choler
not purged, of which I speak not. But when the body is well purged of dry,
yea, or of moist humors, then lackinge moystnes, it must needs follow,
dryness will eftsoons ensue. Then we give water, where in the four cold
seeds, gum Arabike, gum Dragagantum, and cru^mes of bread have bin sodden:
drawn through a strayner, this is given blood warm. Now sir, there is a
dryness, as I have said, which when it comes, declares the body is well
purged, as some men suppose. But therein I take, that they do mistake the
words of Hippocrates: Quicunque in pharmacijs purgantur, Hippocrates.
non fitiunt: non quiescu^t, donec sitiunt: non enim semper bonam purgationem
significat: that is: Who so ever be purged, and thyrst not, the pacie^t takes
no rest, until they do thyrst: this does not always signify, the purging to be
good. Take this for an example. One called Beumayne* has a pletorike body that
is a body full, or replenished with gross humors, aboundauntly compact together
this gross body must be purged: well, he takes a purgacion by Electuarie,
Example.
it works upon Beuman. Now if he feel himself very dry, with a great thyrst,
desiring to drynk after five, six, or seven stools: what is this, a sign
good, or bad? No it is an evil sign, and is proved thus: cholerike or dry
humors be attract, and drawn up into ye stomach, and therefore they are not
expulsed. Whereof there ryseth a hot and a dry phlegm, smoke, or vapor, into
the throat, and spyritual parts: causing the thyrst a foresaid. How to know
whether Choler be purged, or no.
What reamedy for this gross body, then I pray you? None other, but with
speed to give him an other laxatiue medicide, to purge the said choler, and
dry matter, and then the thyrst will soon, or quickly cease. And so in the end,
he shall be better purged of ye grosnes of humors, perhaps than cleansed from ye
corruption of evil conditions. For a bodily medicine ca^ smally preuayl, or
take any effect, in ye Regiment of the Mind or Soul. Also, if such a gross
body as I have named, which is called Pletorike, do wax dry or thrifty,
after.xij.xvj. yea or.xx. stools: the^ is not haot Choler alone in the
stomach, but in all the members of the body. Purge him still with gentle
Electuaries, by little and little, until he feel moisture in his Throat,
and that mutch. And to conclude, whosoever being gross, and very dry, before
his Purgation, is sick of the Fever quotidian, or tercian: the same must be
purged, in the same manner, as I have said before^ What harm Wine does in a
fever, or after purging.
But the lean cholerike man, is soon purged, and when he is dry: let him take
his reamedy, as is a foresaid, a Gods name. It happens also oftentimes, that
the pacient cannot away with cold Water: yea and unknown to the Physician,
the said Pacient drynketh Wine, to his great danger, hurt, and peril: for
thereof follows hot inflamacion, and torment with pains in the belly. If
this do happen, then with speed provoke Uomit, with drynking warm water, and
Sallet oil, thrusting a Fether into the Throat, or a Finger as far as it
may go, and so Uomit. This helps, but do it speedely, my good friend, for
sundry causes, to avoid such danger, as else would follow.


Sickness ONe question I will ask you, because, cause moves me so to do. I

Health. Does cause, cause you to move this question to me? Certain causes
which le^ medicine to work.
I will show you three sundry causes, which let the medicine to make
euacuation, or woorkyng. The first cause may be, by the reason the purgation is
to weakly made: else the dosse or quantity is to little, which remains to the
hurt of the body unpurged. The second cause may be, that the body is to mutch
cold, and subject to melancholy, as me thyncke youres is. The third cause is,
the resol^cion or wasting of humors, does extinguishe or quench the virtue of
ye laxatiue medicine: Example o^ Wax and Fyr^
as it happens sometime in the Phlegmatike bodies In whom, when soever the
phleume begins to dissolve, eftsoons and by and by it quenches, even as
Wax will sometime quench a burninge Charcoale, when it is melted upon it. And
because gross humors are resolved, and cannot be expulsed: then there
follows an importable dolor, Signs of death through purging the body.
and a mighty torment about the stomach, and intrailes. And in ye end, such
solucio^, or none other, but a manifest sign, or peril of death to follow.


Sickness. MAry, this is a poynct next the worst, and an extreme case: it is
